    In the event of disapproval or denial of an application for the permit required by this division, an appeal may be had in the manner provided for appeals in the building code adopted by the city. 
(Code 1984 § 7-111) 
Chapter 7 - BUSINESS REGULATIONS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 7-1-7-5. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUSINESS REGISTRATION FEE 

Sec. 7-6. - Definitions. 
    Unless the context clearly indicates that a different meaning is intended, the words and phrases used in this article shall have the following meanings: 
    Amusement hall means any arcade, building or premises having as its primary business the providing of mechanical or electronic amusement devises, including but not limited to the following: Pinball machines, electronic or video games of skill or chance, claw or scoop machines, jukeboxes, or coin operated table games. 
    Business means any profession, trade or occupation and all and every kind of calling whether or not carried on for profit, except those organizations exempt from the Federal Income Tax pursuant to section 501(c)(3) of the United States Internal Revenue Code of 1954 as amended or renumbered. 
    Canvasser, solicitor or peddler. These terms shall not include the activities of persons who sell solely to other businesses, either of goods or services used in the trade of such other businesses, or of goods for the purpose of resale of such other businesses. 
    Code enforcement department means the department that has responsibility of ensuring compliance with this article and other articles and sections within the Roswell City Code and any other ordinances not incorporated in the Roswell City Code as deemed appropriate by the city manager. 
    Conduct; carry on means engage in, carry on, own, maintain, manage or operate any business, trade, art, profession, calling, employment, occupation or any commercial industrial or professional pursuit, vocation or enterprise in this city. 
    Kiddie ride carnival and exhibits means any carnival and exhibits consisting exclusively of rides and exhibits for children with no amusement devices other than such rides, nor games of chance or skill, and not operating past the hour of 10:00 p.m. 
    Person. For purposes of this article, the word "person" is defined as any person, firm, corporation, partnership, association, company, or organization of whatever kind or nature engaged in the conduct of a trade, profession or business pursuit within the city, which is not otherwise exempt by law or, which has been heretofore otherwise exempt by law or, which has been heretofore enfranchised, licensed or regulated by the city and, excluding from the operation of the article nonprofit, charitable and eleemosynary [of or relating to charities] organizations. 
    Place of business means any location, building or portion thereof, or premises in which or from which a business is carried on. The term includes but is not limited to an office, warehouse, yard, location where books and records are kept, the location from which business is solicited. 
    Temporary displays and sales: means the display or sale of goods, merchandise or services not in or from an enclosed permanent building to be conducted for a period of 120 consecutive hours or less. 
(Code 1984 § 14-15; Ord. No. 1281, 11-1996) 
Sec. 7-7. - Imposition of business registration fee. 
    There is imposed on each place of business conducted in the city a business registration fee of $35.00, pursuant to NMSA 1978, § 3-38-3 as it now exists or is amended or renumbered, under this chapter. The business license registration fee shall not be prorated for businesses conducted for a portion of a year. 
(Code 1984 § 14-16; Ord. No. 1281, 11-1996; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
State Law reference- Business registration, NMSA 1978, § 3-38-3 et seq. 
Sec. 7-8. - Application to do business. 
    Any person proposing to engage in business or the providing of services within the city limits of the City of Roswell shall apply for and pay a business registration fee for each outlet, branch or location or place of business within the city prior to engaging in business, unless such person is required to obtain a business license under this chapter. 
(Code 1984 § 14-17; Ord. No. 1281, 11-1996; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 7-9. - Amount. 
    There is imposed on each place of business conducted in the city an annual business registration fee of $35.00. The business registration fee shall not be prorated for businesses conducted for a portion of year. 
(Code 1984 § 14-18) 
Sec. 7-10. - Registration not transferable. 
    No registration issued pursuant to this article shall be transferable from one business to another, nor from one person conducting business to a succeeding person conducting the same business. If the business changes names a new application will be completed prior to the opening of the business under the new name. 
(Code 1984 § 14-19; Ord. No. 1281, 11-1996) 
Sec. 7-11. - Renewal. 
    A staggered business registration period by quarter is due on the last day of the months of March, June, September, [and] December. 
(1)  Those businesses whose first letter (exclusive of a, an, and the) starts with A through C, numbers, computer codes, etc. license is due on March 31. 
(2)  Those businesses whose first letter (exclusive of a, an, and the) starts with D through K is due on June 30. 
(3)  Those businesses whose first letter (exclusive of a, an, and the) starts with L through R is due on September 30. 
(4)  Those businesses whose first letter (exclusive of a, an, and the) starts with S through Z is due on December 31. 
(5)  If the last day of the month falls on a weekend or a holiday recognized by the City of Roswell, the due date will be the next working day following that weekend or holiday. 
(Code 1984 § 14-20; Ord. No. 1281, 11-1996) 
Sec. 7-12. - Late registration or renewal; late fee. 
(a)  If any person fails to obtain the appropriate registration or license pursuant to the terms of this ordinance, or fails to renew such registration or license before the expiration date of the month of renewal, such person shall pay a late fee in the amount of 20% of the license or registration fee for each month after the payment is late. For this purpose, any portion of the month the fee is late will be considered a full month with the exception of the grace period. 
(b)  A grace period (in which no late fee will be due and payable) of 14 calendar days following the last day of the month the license is to be renewed is allowed. In no event shall the total late fee exceed the cost of the registration or license fee. This section shall be in addition to the penalties and other provisions of section 7-26. 
(Code 1984 § 14-21; Ord. No. 1281, 11-1996: Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999; Ord. No. 00-2, 4-2000) 
Sec. 7-13. - Application. 
    Any person filing an application for issuance or renewal of any business registration or business license shall include in the application the following information: 
(1)  The exact nature or kind of business for which a license is requested; 
(2)  The form of business enterprise under which the business is to be conducted, i.e. sole proprietorship, partnership, limited partnership or corporation. 
(3)  The place where such business is to be carried on, and if the same is not to be carried on at any permanent place of business, the places of residence of the owners of the same; 
(4)  The name or names, other than the name of the applicant, under which the business will be operating, if any; 
(5)  The time of operation during the full 24-hour period and days of operation during a full seven-day week; 
(6)  The names and place of residence of all owners of the business; if the owner is a corporation or partnership, the application shall state the names and places of residence of the officers or general partners thereof; 
(7)  The applicant's current revenue division taxpayer identification number of evidence of application for a current revenue division taxpayer identification number; 
(8)  The number of any state or other license required by the business to be conducted; if necessary to do so or is required by the code enforcement department clerk, the applicant shall attach photocopies or other evidence of having obtained such required licenses; 
(9)  Any required state licenses (i.e. contractor, liquor, etc.), driver's license/state identification card number, and social security number; 
(10)  Such further information as the code enforcement department clerk may deem necessary to enable him/her to issue the certificate applied for. 
(Code 1984 § 14-22; Ord. No. 1281, 11-1996; Ord. No. 00-7, § 3, 9-2000) 
Sec. 7-14. - Registration or license to be displayed. 
    The code enforcement department clerk shall provide a suitable certificate of registration or license to be furnished to each place of business coming within the terms of this ordinance, and such certificate of registration or license shall be prominently displayed at the place of business for which such registration or license is issued. Solicitors and similar licensees shall carry the license on their person while engaging in the business for which such license is issued. 
(Code 1984 § 14-23; Ord. No. 1281, 11-1996) 
Sec. 7-15. - Issuance of duplicate registration or license. 
    A duplicate certificate of registration or license may be issued by the code enforcement department clerk to replace any such registration or license issued under this ordinance which has been lost or destroyed, if the person to whom it was issued files a sworn statement attesting to the fact of such loss or destruction and pays a duplicate fee of $1.00. 
(Code 1984 § 14-24; Ord. No. 1281, 11-1996) 
Sec. 7-16. - Proper business location. 
    No license or registration shall be issued pursuant to this ordinance unless and until the applicant for such license provides the code enforcement department clerk with the address of the proposed location from which the business will be conducted, and the code enforcement department clerk determines that the facilities and buildings at the location listed meet all applicable building and fire code and zoning restrictions currently in force within the city. In his or her discretion, the code enforcement department clerk may issue a temporary license or registration to a business while the applicant is seeking a proper location or bringing a location to current building or fire code requirements not to exceed 60 days. 
(Code 1984 § 14-25; Ord. No. 1281, 11-1996) 
Sec. 7-17. - Offenses; procedure not exclusive. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in conduct or carry on any business or occupation within the City of Roswell without first registering the same or obtaining a license therefor and without first paying the fees, in compliance with the provisions of this ordinance. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly file an application for issuance or renewal of any business registration or business license on which any of the information required by section 7-13 has been falsified. 
(c)  The remedies provided in this section are not exclusive; and if any person engages in business in the City of Roswell without obtaining the required registration or license for such business, the City of Roswell may proceed in any manner authorized by law, including specifically but not limited to the procedures set forth in NMSA 1978, §§ 3-38-5 and 3-38-6. 
(Code 1984 § 14-26; Ord. No. 1281, 11-1996; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 7-18. - Collection remedies. 
    The business registration fee shall constitute a lien in favor of the city upon the personal property of the business and the lien shall have priority over any lien or encumbrance, except a lien for general taxes. Under process or order of the court, no person shall sell the property of any business without first ascertaining from the code enforcement department clerk the amount of any business registration fee due and owing to the city. Any such business registration fee as shall be due and owing to the city shall be paid from the proceeds of sale and before payment is made to the judgment creditor or other person at whose instance such sale is held. Upon request made therefor, the code enforcement department clerk shall furnish a certificate showing the amount of all liens, taxes and interest on record in the city against any such business within the scope of this article. 
(Code 1984 § 14-27; Ord. No. 1281, 11-1996; Ord. No. 00-7, § 3, 9-2000) 
State Law reference- Lien for business license fees, NMSA 1978, § 3-38-6 
Secs. 7-19, 7-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - REGULATORY PERMIT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 7-21. - Required. 
    No person shall engage in any business, occupation or calling for which a regulatory fee is required by division 2 of this article without obtaining a regulatory permit from the business licensing clerk. 
(Code 1984 § 14-31; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Secs. 7-22-7-25. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FEES 

Sec. 7-26. - Receipts. 
    Fees required by this division shall be paid to the business licensing clerk who shall issue receipts evidencing their payment. 
(Code 1984 § 14-46; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 7-27. - Proration. 
    Except as otherwise provided, the fees required by this division shall be calendar year fees. Calendar year fees shall be prorated on a monthly basis if they are paid after the calendar year has begun. Each fraction of a month shall be considered as a full month in computing the fee to be paid. 
(Code 1984 § 14-47) 
Sec. 7-28. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 1243, adopted August 12, 1993, repealed § 14-48 which pertained to itinerant auctioneers and derived from Code 1962, §§ 18-10, 18-11(b). 
Sec. 7-29. - Carnivals. 
    No person shall operate a carnival without paying to the city a regulatory fee of $100.00 per day. 
(Code 1984 § 14-49) 
Sec. 7-30. - Circuses, menageries or wild west shows. 
    No person shall conduct or operate a circus, menagerie or wild west show without paying to the city a regulatory fee based upon the total cost of adult admissions (including reserved seats) as shown below: 
Admission Fee      Fee    
$0.50 or less ..... $ 15.00 
Over $0.50 but not exceeding $0.75 ..... 20.00 
Over $0.75 but not exceeding $1.00 ..... 35.00 
Over $1.00 but not exceeding $1.50 ..... 100.00 
Over $1.50 but not exceeding $2.00 ..... 200.00 
Over $2.00 ..... 250.00 
(Code 1984 § 14-50) 
Sec. 7-31. - Pawnbrokers. 
    No person shall engage in business as a pawnbroker without paying to the city a regulatory fee of $250.00 per year. 
(Code 1984 § 14-52) 
Sec. 7-32. - Miscellaneous amusements. 
    No person shall conduct or operate an amusement park, hall, pavilion or other amusement device or activity for which an admission fee is charged without paying to the city a regulatory fee as prescribed by the governing body, which fee shall be no less than $25.00 and no more than $150.00. 
(Code 1984 § 14-55; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 7-33. - Oversized loads. 
(a)  No person shall drive or move, or for the owner, lessee or other person directing the operation to cause or permit to be driven or moved, on any street any vehicle or vehicles of a size and weight exceeding the limitations stated in NMSA 1978, §§ 66-7-401 through 66-7-416 without paying to the city a regulatory permit of $50.00; if a police escort is needed for said vehicle the regulatory fee is $100.00. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to fire apparatus and road machinery engaged in street construction. 
(Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Secs. 7-34, 7-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DANCES 

Sec. 7-36. - Required. 
    Any person desiring to operate a public dance for one night or a public dance hall continuously in the city shall first obtain a license issued by the governing body. 
(Code 1984 § 14-156) 
Sec. 7-37. - Issuance standards. 
    The governing body shall have the right to refuse to issue a license required by this division if a good cause exists why the license shall not be issued. The license required by this article shall not be issued if its issuance would endanger the public health or the public safety. 
(Code 1984 § 14-157) 
Sec. 7-38. - Fee. 
    No license shall be issued pursuant to this division until the applicant pays the appropriate fee indicated below to the city: 
(1)  For operating a public dance hall continuously, $100.00 per calendar year or any fractional part thereof. 
(2)  For operating a public dance, $10.00 per night. 
(Code 1984 § 14-158) 
Sec. 7-39. - Term. 
    An annual public dance hall license shall expire on January first of the year next following its issuance. 
(Code 1984 § 14-159) 
Sec. 7-40. - Revocation. 
    The governing body may, when any person holding a license under the provisions of this division has been adjudged guilty of violating any ordinances of the city by any court of competent jurisdiction, revoke the license when the public welfare requires it. The governing body may also revoke any license issued under the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1984 § 14-160) 
Secs. 7-41-7-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - GARAGE SALES, YARD SALES, ETC. 

Sec. 7-46. - Purpose. 
    This article is adopted for the express purpose of providing harmony and adequate open spaces for traffic and on-and off-street parking within residential areas, and a distribution of population, parking and traffic which will promote conditions favorable to health, safety, convenience, prosperity and general welfare. 
(Code 1984 § 14-176) 
Sec. 7-47. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Goods means any goods, wares and merchandise or other personal property capable of being the subject of a sale regulated by this article. 
    Person means any person who is occupying any home or mobile home located within a residential district of the city, and who conducts a sale, as defined in this section. 
    Sale of goods means the selling of goods, wares or merchandise in bulk to another within a residential area of the city, commonly known as home, mobile home, garage, patio and yard sales, and other sales activities associated and incidental thereto and held out in such a manner as to reasonably cause the public to believe that the person conducting the sale will cease and discontinue the selling of goods at the place of sale upon disposal of the stock of goods on hand. 
(Code 1984 § 14-177) 
Sec. 7-48. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to or affect the following: 
(1)  Persons acting pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(2)  Persons acting in accordance with their powers and duties as public officials. 
(3)  Duly licensed auctioneers, selling at auction. 
(4)  Any duly licensed, bona fide merchant of the city conducting a seasonal or special sale ordinarily conducted by merchants in the regular course of their business or any bona fide merchant who is closing out his stock of goods and advertises such sale to that effect or any bona fide merchant whose stock of goods has been damaged by fire, smoke, water or otherwise, and who advertises as such. 
(Code 1984 § 14-178) 
Sec. 7-49. - Notice to city. 
    No person shall conduct a garage or other residential sale without first filing with the business licensing clerk a written notice giving the following information: 
(1)  His name and post office address. 
(2)  The location where the sale is to be held. 
(3)  The dates of commencement and termination of the sale. 
(4)  That the seller has not conducted at the location any sale regulated by this article during the 90 days immediately preceding. 
(5)  That the seller acknowledges his liability for payment to the state of gross receipts tax upon the proceeds of any such sale. 
(Code 1984 § 14-179; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 7-50. - False advertising. 
    A person who conducts a garage or other residential sale shall: 
(1)  Refrain from the employment of untrue, deceptive or misleading advertising. 
(2)  Conduct the sale in strict conformity with any advertising or holding out incidental thereto. 
(Code 1984 § 14-180) 
Sec. 7-51. - Maximum length. 
    No person shall conduct a garage or other residential sale so that the selling period pertaining to the sale of goods, exceeds five consecutive days. 
(Code 1984 § 14-181) 
Sec. 7-52. - Frequency. 
    No person shall conduct a garage or other residential sale at the same location within 90 days of another such sale at such location. 
(Code 1984 § 14-182) 
Secs. 7-53-7-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PAWNBROKERS 
DIVISION 1. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 7-56. - Purpose. 
    In recognition of the fact that the business of pawn brokerage, because of the facility it provides for the commission of crime and for its subsequent concealment, is a proper subject for regulation under the police power of the city, that the conduct of such business is a privilege and not a right; and that the conduct of such business is invested with a public interest on behalf of the safety and welfare of the community, this chapter is adopted and shall be construed liberally. 
(Code 1984 § 21-1) 
Sec. 7-57. - Application of chapter to agents and employees. 
    The requirements of this chapter shall apply equally to any agent or employee of a person engaged in the business of a pawnbroker. 
(Code 1984 § 21-2) 
Sec. 7-58. - Furnishing pawnbrokers false information. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly give false information to a pawnbroker. 
(Code 1985 § 21-3) 
Secs. 7-59, 7-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REGULATORY PERMIT 

Sec. 7-61. - Bond as prerequisite. 
    No person shall be issued a regulatory permit as a pawnbroker without having executed a bond to the city approved by the business licensing clerk and the city attorney, in the sum of $5,000.00, with a corporate surety authorized by the laws of the state to write surety bonds, and conditioned for the conduct of such pawnbroker's business according to law and for the due and faithful performance of every provision of this chapter. Such bond shall be for the benefit of the city and of every person damaged by a breach of any condition of this chapter. 
(Code 1984 § 21-16; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999; Ord. No. 00-7, § 3, 9-2000) 
State Law reference- State regulation of pawnbrokers, NMSA 1978. § 58-8-15 et seq.; power of city to legislate for public health, safety and welfare, NMSA 1978, § 3-18-1. 
Sec. 7-62. - Persons eligible. 
    An applicant for a pawnbroker's regulatory permit must be of good moral character and shall not have been convicted of any felony or crime involving moral turpitude. A regulatory permit shall be denied to any applicant whose license has been revoked for cause or who shall have been a partner, officer, director, trustee, manager or stockholder of any corporation or unincorporated association the regulatory permit of which was revoked for cause. 
(Code 1984 § 21-17) 
Sec. 7-63. - Investigation: issuance; notice of denial; appeals. 
    Any applicant for a pawnbroker's regulatory permit shall be referred to the chief of police for investigation as to the personal qualifications of the applicant and as to the truth and accuracy of all statements in the application. In making his investigation, the chief of police shall employ any and all prevailing methods or channels of police inquiry, including but not limited to fingerprints and photographs. As soon thereafter as shall be practicable, the chief of police shall make his report to the business licensing clerk, who shall issue the license only in the event the report is favorable. Within ten days after the business licensing clerk's notice of denial of any such permit, the applicant may appeal in writing any such denial to the governing body. After notice and hearing, the decision of the governing body shall be final. 
(Code 1984 § 21-18; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 7-64. - Transferability: changes in ownership. 
    A pawnbrokers regulatory permit shall not be transferred to another location without the prior consent and approval of the city. A permit is not assignable or transferable to another person. In the event a licensee sells, assigns or otherwise transfers the business, the succeeding owner must obtain a new permit. Any change in the membership of a partnership, ten percent or more of the membership of an association or ten percent or more of the voting stock of a corporation holding a pawnbroker's permit shall constitute a change in ownership of the business. 
(Code 1984 § 21-19) 
Sec. 7-65. - Revocation. 
    Violation of this chapter shall constitute good and sufficient cause for revocation of a pawnbroker's regulatory permit after notice and hearing held before the governing body. The decision of the governing body made, after notice and hearing held, shall be final. 
(Code 1984 § 21-20) 
Secs. 7-66-7-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - RULES OF OPERATION 

Sec. 7-71. - Business hours. 
    Pawnbrokers may operate their businesses only between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. of each day, and shall keep their businesses closed to the public at all other times. 
(Code 1984 § 21-36) 
Sec. 7-72. - Daily reports to chief of police. 
    Every person engaged in the business of a pawnbroker shall furnish daily an accurate and complete report, before 12:00 noon of each business day, to the chief of police, upon blanks to be furnished by the chief of police, which report shall show all property of every kind received or purchased, as well as a description of the property, with serial numbers, if any, the description of the person or persons offering the property to the pawnbroker and such person's address. The report shall give the age, complexion, sex and approximate height of the person delivering the property to the pawnbroker, as well as the date and time the property was received, and the report shall contain any other information as may be required by the chief of police. 
(Code 1984 § 21-37) 
Sec. 7-73. - Maintenance of records. 
    Every person engaged in the business of a pawnbroker in the city shall provide a bound ledger book to be kept at his place of business, in which shall be entered, simultaneously with any pawnbroker transaction, and maintained as a permanent record, an accurate and complete description of every article taken in as a pledge of purchase, including the serial number of the item, if any, and a complete and accurate description of the party or parties from whom the goods are received or purchased, their names and addresses by house numbers and street names. The ledger record shall be and remain open at all times to the chief of police, any member of the police department or other person duly authorized by the chief of police. 
(Code 1984 § 21-38) 
Sec. 7-74. - Falsification of records or information. 
    It shall be unlawful for any pawnbroker to falsify any record required under the provisions of this chapter or for a licensee or any other person to furnish false information in connection with the sale, pledge or exchange of any goods as a pawnbroker. 
(Code 1984 § 21-39) 
Sec. 7-75. - Proof of ownership of pawned goods. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person engaged in the business of a pawnbroker to buy any property of any kind or receive any property as a pledge, which property is plainly and distinctly marked as being the property of any person other than that of the party offering to sell or pledge such property, unless the party offering to sell or pledge such property shall show satisfactory evidence in writing that he is the lawful owner of the property or has been granted permission by the owner to pledge the property. Failure of the pawnbroker or his agents to require such written evidence shall raise a prima facie presumption of guilty knowledge, on the part of the pawnbroker, his agent or employees, that the party offering to pledge or sell such property is not the rightful owner thereof, and shall constitute good and sufficient cause for revocation of the regulatory permit by the governing body, after notice and public hearing held. 
(Code 1984 § 21-40) 
Sec. 7-76. - Stolen property. 
(a)  The chief of police and his authorized representatives have the lawful right to inspect pawned items and may confiscate from a pawnbroker any such item which has been reported as being stolen or which the police department has reason or probable cause to believe has been stolen. The officer confiscating the property shall give a receipt therefor containing sufficient description or information to adequately identify the item taken. 
(b)  The officer confiscating suspect property from a pawnbroker shall proceed without delay to determine whether or not the item was actually contraband or stolen. Should it be determined that the confiscated item was in fact contraband or stolen, the item may be retained as evidence or returned to its rightful owner, otherwise, the property shall be returned to the licensee from whom it was taken. As a condition of being issued a regulatory permit, pawnbrokers shall be under a lawful public duty and shall be required to cooperate fully with the police department in the recovery of stolen property; and, to this end, shall render all reasonable aid and assistance, including but not limited to police inspection of any and all property handled as a pawnbroker. 
(Code 1984 § 21-41) 
Secs. 7-77-7-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS AND CANVASSERS 
DIVISION 1. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 7-81. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Canvasser or solicitor means an individual, whether a resident of the city or not, traveling either by foot, wagon, automobile, motor truck or any other type of conveyance, from place to place, from house to house or from street to street, taking or attempting to take orders for the sale of goods, wares and merchandise, personal property of any nature whatsoever for future delivery or for services to be furnished or performed in the future, whether or not such individual has, carries or exposes for sale a sample of the subject of such sale or whether he is collecting advance payments on such sales or not; provided, that such definition shall include any person who, for himself or for another person, hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, structure, tent, railroad box car, boat, hotel room, lodging house, apartment, shop or any other place within the city for the sole purpose of exhibiting samples and taking orders for future delivery. 
    Peddler means any person, whether a resident of the city or not, traveling by foot, wagon, automotive vehicle or any other type of conveyance, from place to place, from house to house or from street to street, carrying, conveying or transporting goods, wares, merchandise, meats, fish, vegetables, fruits, truck garden, farm products or provisions, offering and exposing the same for sale, or making sales and delivering articles to purchasers or who, without traveling from place to place, shall sell or offer the same for sale from a wagon, automotive vehicle, railroad car or other vehicle or conveyance. One who solicits orders and as a separate transaction, makes deliveries to purchasers as a part of a scheme or design to evade the provisions of this article shall be deemed a peddler subject to the provisions of this chapter. The word "peddler" shall include the words "hawker" and "huckster." 
(Code 1984 § 22-1; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 7-82. - Enforcement. 
    It shall be the duty of any police officer of the city to enforce the provisions of this chapter against any person found to be violating the same. 
(Code 1984 § 22-2) 
Sec. 7-83. - Recordation of violations. 
    The chief of police shall report to the business licensing clerk all convictions for a violation of this chapter. The business licensing clerk shall maintain a record for such license issued and record the reports of the violations therein. 
(Code 1984 § 22-3: Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
State Law reference- Power of city to legislate for public health, safety and welfare, NMSA 1978, § 3-18-1. 
Sec. 7-84. - Registration of charitable solicitors. 
    No persons shall solicit funds for any charitable organization or charitable purpose without first registering with the police department giving their names, addresses and the organizations or causes which they represent. 
(Code 1984 § 22-4) 
Sec. 7-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 7-86. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in business as a peddler, solicitor or canvasser within the city without first obtaining a permit from the city. 
(Code 1984 § 22-16) 
Sec. 7-87. - Application. 
    An applicant for a permit required by this article shall file with the business licensing clerk a sworn application, in writing, in duplicate, on a form to be furnished by the business licensing clerk, which shall give the following information: 
(1)  The name and description of the applicant. 
(2)  The applicant's address, legal and local. 
(3)  A brief description of the nature and the business and the goods to be sold and, in the case of products of farm or orchard, whether produced or grown by the applicant; the place where the goods or property proposed to be sold or orders taken for the sale thereof, are manufactured or produced, where such goods or products are located at the time the application is filed, and the proposed method of delivery. 
(4)  If applicant is employed, the name and address of the employer, together with credentials establishing the exact relationship. 
(5)  The length of time for which the right to do business is desired. 
(6)  If a vehicle is to be used, a description of such vehicle together with its license number or other means of identification. 
(7)  A photograph of the applicant, if requested, to be taken by the police department. 
(Code 1984 § 22-17: Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 7-88. - Persons eligible. 
(a)  No permit required by this article shall be issued to a person who is not of good moral character. 
(b)  The phrase "good moral character" shall be construed to mean the propensity on the part of the person to serve the public in the city in a fair, honest, and open manner. 
(c)  A judgment of guilt in a criminal prosecution or a judgment in a civil action shall not be used, in and of itself, as proof of a person's lack of good moral character. It may be used as evidence in the determination, and when so used the person shall be notified and shall be permitted to rebut the evidence by showing that at the current time he has the ability to, and is likely to serve the public in a fair, honest, and open manner, that he is rehabilitated, or that the substance of the former offense is not reasonably related to the occupation or profession for which he seeks a permit. 
(d)  The following criminal records shall not be used, examined, or requested by the city in a determination of good moral character: 
(1)  Records of an arrest not followed by a conviction. 
(2)  Records of a conviction which has been reversed or vacated, including the arrest records relevant to that conviction. 
(3)  Records of an arrest or conviction for a misdemeanor or a felony unrelated to the person's likelihood to serve the public in a fair, honest, and open manner. 
(4)  Records of an arrest or conviction for a misdemeanor for the conviction of which a person may not be incarcerated in a jail or prison. 
(e)  When a person is found to be unqualified for a permit because of a lack of good moral character, or similar criteria, the person shall be furnished by the business licensing clerk with a statement to this effect. The statement shall contain a complete record of the evidence upon which the determination was based. The person shall be entitled, as of right, to a rehearing on the issue before the business licensing clerk if he has relevant evidence not previously considered regarding his qualifications. 
(Code 1984 § 22-18; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 7-89. - Fee. 
(a)  The fee to be paid to the city for permits required by this article shall be as follows: 
(1)  Ten dollars per week or $25.00 per month for each canvasser or solicitor. 
(2)  Ten dollars per week or $25.00 per month for each peddler. 
(b)  No fee shall be required from any person selling products of the farm or orchard actually produced by the seller in this state. Any person claiming exemption under this subsection shall establish his right to such exemption. 
(c)  Any period of seven calendar days or less shall be considered a week; any period of more than seven calendar days and not more than 30 calendar days shall be considered one month; any period of more than 30 calendar days and not more than one calendar year shall be treated as a year. The annual fees provided for in this section shall be assessed on a calendar year basis, and on and after July first, the amount of the fee for such annual licenses shall be one-half the amount stipulated for the remainder of the year. 
(d)  In any case where a permittee or applicant for a permit believes that the fees prescribed by this article place an undue burden upon interstate commerce, he may apply for an adjustment of the fees imposed thereby, outlining in detail his reason for such contentions under oath and, upon the filing of such complaint with the clerk-treasurer, the business licensing clerk shall have ten days in which to allow or reject the claim as filed. In the event such claim is rejected by the business licensing clerk, the permittee or applicant may appeal in writing to the governing body. Such appeal shall be filed with the business licensing clerk within the time prescribed, and a copy thereof delivered to the mayor. Upon the appeal being perfected as prescribed herein, it shall be considered by the governing body at the next regular meeting thereof, at which time the permittee or applicant shall have an opportunity to appear in person and by attorney. No compliant shall be considered by the business licensing clerk or the governing body unless filed before, at or within three months after payment of the prescribed permit fee. The application to be signed under the provisions of this article shall advise the applicant of this section. 
(Code 1984 § 22-19; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 7-90. - Bond. 
    Every applicant for a permit under this article shall file with the business licensing clerk a surety bond, running to the city, in the amount of $1,000.00, with surety acceptable to and approved by the business licensing clerk, conditioned that the applicant shall comply fully with all ordinances of the city and the statutes of the state regulating and concerning the business licensed and guaranteeing to any citizen of the city that all money paid will be accounted for and applied according to the representations of the permittee, and further guaranteeing to any resident of the city doing business with the licensee that the property purchased will be delivered according to the representations made by the permittee and will conform to such representations, whether such representations be oral or in writing. Action on such bond may be brought in the name of the city to the use or benefit of the aggrieved person. The business licensing clerk may waive such bond. 
(Code 1984 § 22-20; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 7-91. - Investigation and issuance. 
    Upon receipt of the application for a permit under this article, the original shall be referred to the chief of police, who shall cause such investigation of the applicant's business and moral character to be made as he deems necessary for the protection of the public good. If, as a result of such investigation, the character and business responsibility of the applicant are found to be satisfactory, the chief of police shall endorse on the application his approval, execute a permit addressed to the applicant for the carrying on of the business applied for and return the permit, along with the application, to the business licensing clerk, who shall, upon payment of the prescribed fee, deliver to the applicant his permit. 
(Code 1982 § 22-21; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 7-92. - Contents. 
    A permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this article shall contain signature and seal of the issuing officer and shall show the name, address and photograph of the permittee, the class of license issued and the kind of goods to be sold thereunder, the amount of fee paid, the date of issuance and the length of time the same shall be operative, as well as the license number and other identifying description of any vehicle used in peddling. 
(Code 1984 § 22-22) 
Sec. 7-93. - Records. 
    The business licensing clerk shall keep a record of all permits issued pursuant to the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1984 § 22-23; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 7-94. - Display. 
    Any person issued a permit under the provisions of this article shall exhibit his permit at the request of any person with whom he seeks to negotiate for business in the city. 
(Code 1984 § 22-24) 
Sec. 7-95. - Revocation. 
    Permits issued under the provisions of this article may be revoked by the business licensing clerk, after notice and hearing, for any one of the following causes: 
(1)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for the permit. 
(2)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in the course of carrying on his business as solicitor, peddler or as canvasser. 
(3)  Any violation of this chapter. 
(4)  Conviction of any crime or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude. 
(5)  Conducting the business of soliciting, peddling or of canvassing in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public. 
(Code 1984 § 22-25; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 7-96. - Appeals. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article, any applicant for a permit required by this article who is aggrieved by the actions of the chief of police or the business licensing clerk under this article shall have the right of appeal to the governing body, provided, that such appeal shall be taken by filing with the business licensing clerk, within 14 days after notice of the action complained of has been mailed to such person's last known address, a written statement setting forth fully the grounds for the appeal. Thereupon, the governing body shall set a time and place for a hearing on such appeal, and notice of such hearing shall be given to the appellant in the same manner as provided in section 7-95 for notice of hearing on revocations. The decision and order of the governing body on such appeal shall be final and conclusive. 
(Code 1984 § 22-26; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999; Ord. No. 00-7, § 3, 9-2000) 
Secs. 7-97-7-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - AMUSEMENTS 

Sec. 7-101. - Sanitation. 
    Any carnival show, show, circus, menagerie or wild west show showing or giving performances within the city shall at all times keep its grounds in a clean sanitary manner and shall, upon discontinuing the performance, clean up its show grounds and leave them in a clean and sanitary manner. 
(Code 1984 § 4-16) 
Sec. 7-102. - Filing of schedule of prices. 
    All shows, circuses, carnival shows, wild west shows and menageries desiring to operate within the city shall, at the time application for a regulatory permit is made, file a schedule of prices to be charged, which schedule shall include the cost of admission to the main show, the cost of reserved seats. and the charge of admission to each side show. 
(Code 1984 § 4-17) 
State Law reference- Power of city to legislate for public health, safety and welfare, NMSA 1978, § 3-18-1. 
Secs. 7-103-7-105. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - TRANSIENT AND ITINERANT MERCHANTS AND ITINERANT VENDORS 
DIVISION 1. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 7-106. - Definition. 
(a)  For the purpose of this article, a transient merchant, itinerant merchant or itinerant vendor is defined as any person, whether as owner, agent, consignee or employee, whether a resident of the city or not, who engages in a temporary business of selling and delivering goods, wares and merchandise within the city, and who, in furtherance of such purpose, hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, structure, motor vehicle, tent, railroad boxcar, public room in hotels, lodging houses, apartments, shops, or any street, alley, or other place within the city, for the exhibition and sale of such goods, wares and merchandise, either privately or at public auction; provided, that such definition shall not be construed to include any person who, while occupying such temporary location, does not sell from stock, but exhibits samples only for the purpose of securing orders for future delivery only. The person so engaged shall not be relieved from complying with the provisions of this chapter merely by reason of associating temporarily with any local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer, or by conducting such transient business in connection with, as a part of, or in the name of any local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer. 
(b)  For purposes of this chapter, "temporary" shall refer to activities whose expected duration is less than 120 consecutive hours. 
(Code 1984 § 30-1) 
Sec. 7-107. - Enforcement by police. 
    Code enforcement and police officers of the city shall examine all places of business and persons subject to the provisions of this chapter to determine if this chapter has been complied with, and shall enforce the provisions of this chapter against any person found to be violating such provisions. 
(Code 1984 § 30-2; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 7-108. - City records, reports, etc. 
    The police department shall attain the record of fingerprints of each licensee under this chapter, together with the license number. The chief of police shall report to the business licensing clerk any complaints against any person licensed under the provisions of this chapter and any convictions for a violation of this chapter. The business licensing clerk shall keep a record of all such licenses and of such complaints and violations. 
(Code 1984 § 30-3; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 7-109. - City's right to observe sales and inspect books. 
    The business licensing clerk or his designee shall have the power and authority to enter any store, building or any other place in which any temporary business regulated by this chapter may be conducted at any time during business hours for ascertaining the amount of sales made and shall at all times have access to the books of such business. 
(Code 1984 § 30-4; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
State Law reference- Power of city to legislate for public health, safety or welfare, NMSA 1978, § 3-18-1. 
Sec. 7-110. - Noise. 
    No licensee under this chapter, nor anyone in his behalf, shall shout, make an outcry, blow a horn, ring a bell or use any other sound device including any loud speaking radio or amplifying system upon any of the streets, alleys, parks or other public places of the city or upon any private premises in the city where sound of sufficient volume is emitted or produced therefrom capable of being plainly heard upon the streets, avenues, alleys or parks or other public places, for the purpose of attracting attention to any goods, wares or merchandise which such licensee proposes to sell. 
(Code 1984 § 30-5) 
Secs. 7-111-7-115. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 7-116. - Required. 
    No transient merchant, itinerant merchant or itinerant vendor shall engage in such business within the city without first obtaining a license therefor in compliance with the provisions of this article. No license shall be required of individual exhibitors and dealers participating in an organized craft or trade fair providing the sponsoring organization has itself obtained a license. 
(Code 1984 § 30-21) 
Sec. 7-117. - Application. 
(a)  Applicants for a license under this article shall file a written sworn application signed by the applicant if an individual, by all partners if a partnership, and by the president if a corporation, with the business licensing clerk, showing: 
(1)  The name of the person having the management or supervision of the applicant's business during the time that it is proposed that it will be carried on in the city; the local address of such person while engaged in such business; the permanent address of such person; the capacity in which such person will act, that is, whether as proprietor, agent or otherwise; the name and address of the person for whose account the business will be carried on, if any; and if a corporation, under the laws of what state the corporation is incorporated. 
(2)  The fingerprints of the person having the management or supervision of applicant's business or in lieu thereof, at least three letters of recommendation from reliable property owners in the county certifying as to the applicant's good character and business responsibility, or other evidence which establishes to the satisfaction of the business licensing clerk the good character and business responsibility of such person. 
(3)  The place in the city where it is proposed to carry on applicant's business, and the length of time during which it is proposed that such business shall be conducted. 
(4)  The place, other than the permanent place of business of the applicant where applicant within the six months next preceding the date of the application conducted a transient business, stating the nature thereof and giving the post office and street address of any building or office in which such business was conducted. 
(5)  A statement of the nature, character and quality of the goods, wares or merchandise to be sold or offered for sale by applicant in the city, the invoice value and quality of such goods, wares and merchandise, whether they are proposed to be sold from stock in possession or from possession and by sample; at auction, by direct sale or by indirect sale and by taking orders for future delivery; where the goods or property proposed to be sold are manufactured or produced and where such goods or products are located at the time such application is filed. 
(6)  A brief statement of the nature and character of the advertising done or proposed to be done in order to attract customers, and, if required by the business licensing clerk, copies of all such advertising, whether by handbills, circulars, newspaper advertising or otherwise, shall be attached to the application as exhibits thereto. 
(7)  Whether or not the person having the management or supervision of the applicant's business has been convicted of a crime, misdemeanor or the violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of such offense and the punishment assessed therefor. 
(8)  Credentials from the person for which the applicant proposes to do business, authorizing the applicant to act as such representative. 
(9)  Such other reasonable information as to the identity or character of the person having the management or supervision of applicant's business or the method or plan of doing such business as the business licensing clerk may deem proper to fulfill the purpose of this chapter in the protection of the public good. 
(b)  All applications for licenses shall be submitted at least seven days in advance of the period for which the license is sought. 
(Code 1984 § 30-22; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 7-118. - Fee. 
    Licensees under this article shall pay a fee of $100.00 for each 120-hour period covered by the license. 
(Code 1984 § 30-23) 
Sec. 7-119. - Persons eligible. 
(a)  No license required by this article shall be issued to a person who is not of good moral character. 
(b)  The phrase "good moral character" shall be construed to mean the propensity on the part of the person to serve the public in the licensed area in a fair, honest, and open manner. 
(c)  A judgment of guilt in a criminal prosecution or a judgment in a civil action shall not be used, in and of itself, as proof of a person's lack of good moral character. It may be used as evidence in the determination, and when so used the person shall be notified and shall be permitted to rebut the evidence by showing that at the current time he has the ability to, and is likely to serve the public in a fair, honest, and open manner, that he is rehabilitated, or that the substance of the former offence is not reasonably related to the occupation or profession for which he seeks to be licensed. 
(d)  The following criminal records shall not be used, examined, or requested by the city in a determination of good moral character: 
(1)  Records of an arrest not followed by a conviction. 
(2)  Records of a conviction which has been reversed or vacated, including the arrest records relevant to that conviction. 
(3)  Records of an arrest or conviction for a misdemeanor or a felony unrelated to the person's likelihood to serve the public in a fair, honest, and open manner. 
(4)  Records of an arrest or conviction for a misdemeanor for the conviction of which a person may not be incarcerated in a jail or prison. 
(e)  When a person is found to be unqualified for a license because of a lack of good moral character, or similar criteria, the person shall be furnished by the business licensing clerk with a statement to this effect. The statement shall contain a complete record of the evidence upon which the determination was based. The person shall be entitled, as of right, to a rehearing on the issue before the business licensing clerk if he has relevant evidence not previously considered regarding his qualifications. 
(Code 1984 § 30-24; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999; Ord. No. 00-7, § 3, 9-2000) 
Sec. 7-120. - Bond. 
    Before any license required by this article shall be issued, the applicant shall file with the business licensing clerk a bond running to the city in the sum of $1,000.00 executed by the applicant, as principal, and two sureties upon which service of process may be made in the state, such bond to be approved by the business licensing clerk, conditioned that the applicant shall comply fully with all the provisions of all ordinances of the city and the statutes of the state regulating and concerning the sale of goods, wares and merchandise, and will pay all judgments rendered against the applicant for any violation of such ordinances or statutes or any of them, together with all judgments and costs that may be recovered against him by any person for damage growing out of any misrepresentation or deception practiced on any person transacting such business with such applicant, whether such misrepresentations or deceptions were made or practiced by the owners or by their servants, agents or employees, either at the time of making the sale or through any advertisement of any character whatsoever, printed or circulated with reference to the goods, wares and merchandise sold or any part thereof. Action on the bond may be brought in the name of the city to the use of the aggrieved person. Such bond must be approved by the business licensing clerk, both as to form and as to the responsibility of the sureties thereon. 
(Code 1984 § 30-25; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 7-121. - Service of process. 
    Before any license required by this article shall be issued, the applicant shall file with the business licensing clerk an instrument nominating and appointing the business licensing clerk or the person performing the duties of such position his true and lawful agent, with full power and authority to acknowledge service or notice of process for and on behalf of the applicant in respect to any matters connected with or arising out of the business transacted under the license and the bond given or for the performance of the conditions of the bond or for any breach thereof. The instrument shall also contain recitals to the effect that the applicant for the license consents and agrees that service of any notice or process may be made upon such agent and when so made shall be taken and held to be as valid as if personally served upon the person applying for the license under this article according to the law of this or any other state, and waiving all claim or right or error by reason of such acknowledgment of service or manner of service. Immediately upon service of process upon the business licensing clerk, the business licensing clerk shall send to the licensee at his last known address, by registered mail, a copy of such process. 
(Code 1984 § 30-26; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 7-122. - Investigation and issuance. 
    Upon receipt of an application for a license under this article, the business licensing clerk shall cause such investigation of such person's business responsibility or moral character to be made as he deems necessary to the protection of the public good. If, as a result of such investigation, the applicant's character and business reputation appear to be satisfactory, the business licensing clerk shall so certify in writing, and a license shall be issued. The business licensing clerk shall keep a full record in his office of all licenses issued. 
(Code 1984 § 30-27; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 7-123. - Form. 
    A license issued pursuant to the provisions of this article shall contain the number of the license, the date the license is issued, the nature of the business authorized to be carried on the amount of the license fee paid, the expiration date of such license, the place where such business may be carried on under such license, and the name of the person authorized to carry on such business. 
(Code 1984 § 30-28) 
Sec. 7-124. - Display. 
    Each license issued under this article shall be posted conspicuously in the place of business named therein. In the event that the person applying for the license shall desire to do business in more than one place within the city, separate licenses may be issued for each place of business and shall be posted conspicuously in each place of business. 
(Code 1984 § 30-29) 
Sec. 7-125. - Transferability. 
    No license issued under this article shall be transferred without written consent from the mayor as evidenced by an endorsement on the face of the license by the business licensing clerk showing to whom the license is transferred and the date of the transfer. 
(Code 1984 § 30-30; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 7-126. - Revocation. 
(a)  Licenses issued pursuant to this article may be revoked by the business licensing clerk, after notice and hearing, for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statements contained in the application for the license. 
(2)  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in connection with the selling of goods, wares or merchandise. 
(3)  Any violation of this chapter. 
(4)  Conviction of the licensee of any felony or of a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude. 
(5)  Conducting the business licensed under this chapter in any unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety and general welfare of the public. 
(b)  Notice of hearing for revocation of license shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of the complaint and the time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the licensee, at his last known address, at least five days prior to the date set for the hearing. 
(Code 1984 § 30-31; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 7-127. - Appeals. 
    Any person aggrieved by the decision of the business licensing clerk in regard to the denial of the application for a license or in connection with the revocation of a license required by this article shall have the right to appeal to the governing body. Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the governing body within 14 days after notice of the decision by the business licensing clerk has been mailed to such person's last known address, a written statement setting forth the grounds for the appeal. The governing body shall set the time and place for a hearing on such appeal and notice of such hearing shall be given to such person in the same manner, as is provided for notice of hearing on revocation. The order of the governing body on such appeal shall be final. 
(Code 1984 § 30-32; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Secs. 7-128, 7-129. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - ALARMS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 14-03 , adopted Oct. 9, 2014, amended art. X in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former art. X, §§ 7-130-7-144 pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 01-04; and Ord. No. 02-12. 

Sec. 7-130. - Purpose and scope. 
    This article authorizes the Roswell Police Chief to create a program to govern burglary, panic, duress and robbery alarm systems; require permits, establish fees, provide for restricted response to alarm sites, and provide for fines for violations. The purpose of this article is to encourage alarm users and alarm companies to properly use and maintain the operational effectiveness and proper utilization of alarm systems and to reduce false alarms which may unduly divert police officers from their law enforcement duties. 
( Ord. No. 14-03 , § 1, 10-9-2014) 
Sec. 7-131. - Definitions. 
    In this article: 
    Alarm administrator means a person or persons designated by the Roswell Police Chief to administer, control and review false alarm reduction efforts and administer this article. 
    Alarm dispatch request means a request to the Roswell Police Department to respond to and investigate a burglar, panic, duress or robbery alarm activation at a particular alarm site. 
    Alarm installation or servicing company means a person in the business of selling, providing, maintaining, servicing, repairing, altering, replacing, moving or installing an alarm system in an alarm site. This definition shall also include individuals or businesses that install and service the alarm systems that will be used in their private or proprietary facilities. This does not include persons doing installation or repair work where such work is performed without compensation of any kind (i.e., "do-it- yourselfers"). 
    Alarm monitoring means the process by which an alarm monitoring company receives signals from an alarm system and relays an alarm dispatch request to the Roswell Police Department for the purpose of summoning public safety to the alarm site. 
    Alarm monitoring company means a person in the business of providing alarm monitoring services. 
    Alarm response manager (ARM) or customer care/police coordinator means a person designated by an alarm installation company to handle alarm issues for the company and act as the primary point of contact for the jurisdiction's alarm administrator. 
    Alarm registration (or police response pennit) means the authorization granted by the alarm administrator to the alarm user to operate an alarm system and the authorization to the alarm user to request police dispatch to an alarm site to investigate an alarm activation. 
    Alarm site means a single fixed premises or location served by an alarm system or systems. Each unit, if served by a separate alarm system in a multi-tenant building or complex, shall be considered a separate alarm site. 
    Alarm system means a device or series of devices, including, but not limited to, hardwired systems and systems interconnected with a radio frequency method such as cellular or private radio signals, which emit or transmit a remote or local audible, visual or electronic signal indicating an alarm condition and intended to summon public safety response. Alarm system does not include an alarm installed in a motor vehicle or a boat unless the motor vehicle or boat is permanently located at a site or the alarm activation is relayed to an alarm monitoring company. 
    Alarm user means any person, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity that occupies an alarm site and uses or is in primary control of the operation of the alarm system at the alarm site to include the responsibility of family members, guests, employees and work crews with access to the alarm site. In the case of a residential, business or government rental property, the tenant is considered the alarm user. 
    ANSI/SIA control panel standard CP-01 means the ANSI-American National Standard Institute approved Security Industry Association - SIA CP-01 Control Panel Standard, as may be updated from time to time, that details recommended design features for alarm system control panels and their associated arming and disarming devices to reduce the incidence of false alarms. Control panels build and tested to this standard by underwriters laboratory (UL), or other nationally recognized testing organizations, will be marked to state "Design evaluated in accordance with SIA-CP-01 Control Panel Standard Features for False Alarm Reduction." 
    Automatic voice dialer means any electrical, electronic, mechanical or other device capable of being programmed to send a prerecorded voice message, when activated, over a telephone line, radio or other communication system, to a public safety or emergency services agency requesting dispatch. 
    Cancellation means the process where police response to an activated alarm is terminated by an alarm monitoring company for the alarm site by notifying the Roswell Police Department that there is not an existing situation at the alarm site requiring public safety response. 
    Duress alarm means a silent alarm system signal generated by the entry of a designated code into an arming station in order to signal that the alarm user is being forced to turn off the system and requires public safety response. 
    Enhanced call verification (ECV) is a monitoring procedure requiring that an alarm or monitoring service make a minimum of two telephone calls to the alarm user or a representative prior to making an alarm dispatch request in an attempt to verify that the police should be dispatched. The two calls must be made to different phone numbers, if available, where an alarm user can typically be reached. Enhanced call verification procedures will apply only to burglar alarm activations and not to panic, hold-up or other user-activated alarms or in cases where a crime-in-progress has been verified by real-time audio or video surveillance of an alarm site by the alarm monitoring company. 
    False alarm means a burglar, panic, duress or robbery alarm activation, local or monitored, investigated by the Roswell Police Department where the responding officer finds no evidence of a criminal offense, attempted criminal offense or other emergency after having completed a timely investigation of the alarm site. A false alarm does not include an alarm signal caused by extraordinary violent conditions of nature. 
    Holdup/robbery alarm means a silent alarm signal generated by the manual activation of a device intended to signal a robbery in progress. 
    Keyholder means an individual capable of reaching and having access to the alarm site, the code to the alarm system and the authority to approve repairs to the alarm system. 
    Local alarm system means any alarm system, which is not monitored, that annunciates an alarm only at the alarm site. 
    One plus duress alarm means the manual activation of a silent alarm signal by entering a code at an arming station that adds one to the last digit of the normal arm/disarm code. 
    Panic alarm means an audible alarm system signal generated by the manual activation of a device intended to signal a life threatening or emergency situation requiring public safety response. 
    Person means an individual, corporation, partnership, association, organization or similar entity. 
    Restricted response means that police response to burglar alarms at a specified alarm site will not be made due to excessive false alarms or other violation of the alarm ordinance. Police response will continue to be made to all duress, panic and robbery alarms and to burglar alarms where it have been verified by an eye-witness, or through the monitoring of visual or audio devices that a crime is being or has been committed. 
    Unregistered alarm site means a site that has not complied with a jurisdiction's registration requirements as defined in the alarm ordinance. 
    Verify means an attempt, by the alarm monitoring company, to determine the validity of an alarm signal prior to initiating an alarm dispatch request. 
    Zones means the capability of an alarm system to report alarm activations by area. 
( Ord. No. 14-03 , § 1, 10-9-2014) 
Sec. 7-132. - Registration. 
(a)  Registration required. No alarm user shall operate, or cause to be operated, an alarm system at its alarm site without a valid alarm registration. A separate registration is required for each alarm site. 
(b)  Registration term. Alarm registrations are valid for one year after the registration date. The alarm administrator shall notify each alarm user of the need to renew at least 30 days prior to the expiration of the registration. It is the responsibility of the alarm user to renew the registration prior to expiration date. Failure to renew will be classified as use of a non-registered alarm system and citations and penalties shall be assessed. 
(c)  Application. The police response permit shall be requested on an application form provided by the alarm administrator. The alarm user has the duty to obtain an application from the alarm administrator. 
(d)  Transfer of possession. When the possession of the alarm site is transferred, the alarm user obtaining possession of the alarm site shall file an application for an alarm registration within 30 days of obtaining possession of the alarm site. Alarm registrations are not transferable. 
(e)  Reporting updated information. Whenever the information provided on the alarm registration application changes, the alarm user shall provide correct information to the alarm administrator within 30 days of the change. In addition, each year after the issuance of the police response permit, police response permit holders will receive from the alarm administrator a form requesting updated information. The police response permit holder shall complete and return this form to the alarm administrator when any of the requested information has changed; failure to comply will constitute a violation and may result in a civil penalty. 
(f)  Initial alarm registration fee. The fee for an initial alarm is $25.00 and shall be paid by the alarm user. No refund of a registration will be made. The initial annual registration fee must be submitted to the alarm administrator within 30 days after the alarm installation or alarm system takeover. Residential alarmed sites occupied by an individual 62 years old or older will have the registration fee waived. This waiver applies to senior residential sites and not business sites. Alarm sites occupied by a municipal, county, state or federal government agency will have the initial registration waived. Senior alarm sites and government alarm sites are still subject to false alarm fines. 
(g)  Renewal alarm registration fee. The fee for an alarm registration renewal is $25.00 and shall be paid by the alarm user. The fee for a renewal of an alarm site that has had no charged false alarm police responses during the registration's previous 12-month registration shall be waived. No refund of a registration or registration renewal fee will be made. Residential alarm sites occupied by an individual 62 years old or older will have the registration renewal fee waived. Alarm sites occupied by a municipal, county, state or federal government agency will have the renewal fee waived. 
( Ord. No. 14-03 , § 1, 10-9-2014) 
Sec. 7-133. - Registration required to operate an alarm business. 
    It is unlawful for any person, partnership, corporation or association to own, manage, conduct or carry on the business of selling, leasing, installing, servicing, maintaining, repairing, replacing, moving or removing, or causing to be sold, leased, installed, serviced, maintained, repaired, replaced, moved or removed in or on any building or other property within the city any device known as an intrusion or physical duress alarm system, or automatic dialing device connected to an answering service , unless they possess a valid license issued by the Construction Industries Division of the Regulation and Licensing Department of the State of New Mexico and a City of Roswell business license. Licenses must be presented to the chief of police or his designee representative upon request. 
( Ord. No. 14-03 , § 1, 10-9-2014) 
Sec. 7-134. - Alarm systems in tenant residential, business and government units. 
(a)  A tenant with an alarm system shall obtain an alarm registration from the alarm administrator before operating or causing the operation of an alarm system in the tenant's residential, business or government unit. The owner or property manager of a rented complex shall obtain a separate alarm registration for any alarm system operated in the owner's or manager's offices or common areas of the complex. 
(b)  For purposes of enforcing this article against an individual residential, business or government unit, the tenant is considered as the alarm user and is responsible for obtaining the alarm permit, submitting the permit fees and fines, assuming responsibility for all employees, guests, family members and work crews with access to the alarm site. Each individual alarmed residential, business or government unit within a building shall be considered a separate alarm site. 
( Ord. No. 14-03 , § 1, 10-9-2014) 
Sec. 7-135. - Duties of the alarm user. 
    An alarm user shall: 
(1)  Maintain the premises and the alarm system in a method that will reduce or eliminate false alarms. 
(2)  Respond or cause a representative who has access to an alarm site to respond to the alarm system's location within 30 minutes when notified by the police department. 
(3)  Obtain a new police response permit and pay any associated fees if there is a change in ownership of a business or residence. 
(4)  Not manually activate an alarm for any reason other than an occurrence of an event that the alarm system was intended to report. 
(5)  Adjust the mechanism or cause the mechanism to be adjusted so that an alarm signal audible on the exterior of an alarm site will sound for no longer than ten minutes after being activated. 
(6)  Have a licensed alarm installation or servicing company inspect the alarm system after two false alarms in a one-year period. The alarm administrator may waive a required inspection if it determines that a false alarm(s) could not have been related to a defect or malfunction in the alarm system. After four false alarms within a one-year period, the alarm user must have a licensed alarm installation or servicing company modify the alarm system to be more false alarm resistant, if required, and/or provide additional user training as appropriate. 
(7)  Not use automatic voice dialers. 
(8)  Maintain a set of written operating instructions for each alarm system at each alarm site. 
(9)  Inform their alarm installation or servicing company of any change that alters any of the information listed in their paperwork with the alarm installation or servicing company within five business days of such change. 
(10)  Notify their alarm installation or servicing company, alarm monitoring company and the alarm administrator within five business days if the alarm system is disconnected or terminated, or if the contracted alarm user or business moves or the alarm site is sold. 
(11)  The alarm user will require that their alarm and monitoring company utilize enhanced call verification, where prior to requesting a police dispatch to an activated burglar alarm, the alarm or monitoring company will make a minimum of two telephone calls at two different telephones, when available to the alarm user in an attempt to verify that the police should be dispatched. Enhanced call verification procedures will apply only to burglar alarm activations and not to panic, hold-up or any other user-activated alarms or in cases where a crime-in-progress has been verified by a real-time audio or video surveillance of the alarm site by the alarm monitoring company. 
(12)  This section also applies to all individuals and businesses, who have installed and/or monitor their own alarm system. 
( Ord. No. 14-03 , § 1, 10-9-2014) 
Sec. 7-136. - Duties of alarm installation, servicing and monitoring company. 
    Each alarm installation, servicing or monitoring company shall: 
(1)  Maintain a license as required by the locality and state. Furnish license numbers to the alarm administrator on request. 
(2)  Connect and program the detectors in the alarm system to report detailed zone and detector information on the type and location of each device. 
(3)  Take reasonable measures to prevent the occurrence of false alarms. 
(4)  Provide written and oral instructions to each of its alarm users in the proper use and operation of their alarm systems. Such instructions will specifically include all instructions necessary to turn the alarm system on and off (arm and disarm) and how to cancel an alarm. 
(5)  Be available to maintain the alarm system in good working order. 
(6)  Provide written information on how to obtain service from the alarm installation, servicing or monitoring company for the alarm system. 
(7)  Use only ANSI/SIA CP-01 listed alarm control panels on all new installations and panel replacements or upgrades. 
(8)  Ensure that all alarm users of alarm systems equipped with a duress, hold up, robbery or panic alarm are given adequate training. 
(9)  Provide new customers with a summarized copy of this article and an alarm user registration application. 
(10)  Notify the alarm administrator if it takes over responsibility for alarm system accounts from another person and provide details as may be reasonable requested the alarm administrator. 
(11)  Designate an alarm response manager (ARM) for the company to manage alarm related issues and act as the point of contact for the alarm administrator. The ARM must be knowledgeable of the general provisions of the ordinance as well as have the knowledge and authority to deal with false alarm issues and respond to requests from the alarms administrator. The name, phone number and email address of the ARM must be provided to the alarm administrator and updated on an annual basis or whereupon the designated ARM changes. 
(12)  Provide the alarm administrator with a customer list in a format acceptable to the alarm administrator upon request to assist the alarm administrator with creating tracking data. 
(13)  Not use automatic voice dialers. 
(14)  Not program alarm systems so that they are capable of sending one plus duress alarms. The alarm installation or servicing company shall remove the one plus duress feature from alarm systems whenever and alarm technician is at the alarm site.
