(15)  Not install a device to activate a holdup, robbery, duress or panic alarm which is a single action non-recessed button. 
(16)  Notify the alarm monitoring company (if separate from the alarm installation or servicing company) if it takes over responsibility for alarm system accounts from another person or company. 
(17)  Notify their alarm monitoring company of an alarm system account termination within five days of termination/cancellation. 
(18)  Offer the alarm user the use of a seven-day training period in which the alarm user will adequately train in the proper use of the alarm system. No request for dispatch by the alarm company or alarm monitoring company will be made during this training period for a burglar alarm signal. Police dispatch requests will be made during the training period for panic, duress and holdup signals. 
(19)  Communicate alarm dispatch requests and cancellations using public safety telephone numbers designated by the alarm administrator. 
(20)  Utilize enhanced call verification for burglar alarms. 
(21)  Communicate any available information related to the alarm dispatch request including: 
a.  Alarm user registration number. 
b.  Nature of the alarm (i.e., fire, burglary, robbery, panic, duress, silent or audible). 
c.  Specific location of all alarm signals (interior or perimeter, north, front, etc.) 
d.  Advise that the alarm user or the keyholder is on the way to the alarm site with the estimated time of arrival and description of the vehicle. 
e.  Alarm monitoring company operator name, identification number, and call back telephone number. 
(22)  Contact the alarm user or keyholder within 24 hours via mail, fax, telephone or other electronic means when an alarm dispatch request is made. 
(23)  Maintain for a period of at least one year from the date of the alarm dispatch request, records relating to the alarm dispatch request. Records must include the name, address and telephone number of the alarm user, the alarm system zone(s) activated, the time of alarm dispatch request and evidence of an attempt to verify. The alarm administrator may request copies of such records for individually named alarm users. If the request is made within 60 days of an alarm dispatch request, the alarm monitoring company shall furnish requested records within three business days of receiving the request. If the records are requested between 60 days to one year after an alarm dispatch request, the alarm monitoring company shall furnish the requested records within 30 days of receiving the request. 
(24)  An alarm company or monitoring company shall not make an alarm dispatch request to the Roswell Police to a location that has been placed on restricted response status without verifying that a crime is being or has been committed. 
( Ord. No. 14-03 , § 1, 10-9-2014) 
Sec. 7-137. - Duties of the alarm administrator. 
(a)  The alarm administrator shall: 
(1)  Designate a manner, form and telephone numbers for the communication of alarm dispatch requests; 
(2)  Establish a procedure to accept cancellation of alarm dispatch requests; 
(3)  Establish a procedure to record such information on alarm dispatch requests necessary to permit the alarm administrator to maintain records; 
(4)  Establish a procedure for the notification to the alarm user of a false alarm; 
(5)  Make a copy of this article and/or an ordinance summary sheet available to the alarm user; 
(6)  Upon receipt of a completed alarm registration application form and the alarm registration fee, the alarm administrator shall register the applicant unless the applicant has failed to pay a fine or fee assessed under this article; or had the alarm site placed under restricted response and the violation causing the restricted response status has not been corrected; 
(7)  Notify the alarm user in writing after each billable false alarm. The notification shall include the amount of the fine for the false alarm, the fact that the alarm site will be placed on restricted response with the eighth false alarm and a description of the appeals procedure available to the alarm user; 
(8)  Notify the alarm user and the alarm company or alarm monitoring company in writing at least ten days before the alarm site is to be placed on restricted response status. This notice of restricted response will also include the amount of the fine for each false alarm and a description of the appeals procedure available to the alarm user and the alarm company or alarm monitoring company; 
(9)  The alarm administrator has the authority to waive any fines and fees, change the alarm permit status and delete false alarm records from alarm permits. 
(b)  The alarm administrator may: 
(1)  Require a conference with an alarm user and the alarm installation company and/or the alarm monitoring company responsible for the repair or monitoring of the alarm system to review the circumstances of each false alarm. 
(2)  Create and implement an alarm user awareness class. The alarm administrator may request the assistance of associations, alarm companies and public safety agencies in developing and implementing the class. The class shall inform alarm users of the problems created by false alarms and teach alarm users how to avoid causing false alarms. 
(3)  Require an alarm user to remove or replace a holdup alarm device that is a single action, non-recessed button, with an acceptable dual-action or recessed device after the occurrence of a false hold up alarm. 
(4)  Require an alarm user to remove the duress or panic alarm capability from their alarm system after the occurrence of a false alarm. 
(5)  Require an alarm user to upgrade their alarm system or change the manner in which dispatches are requested in order to reduce false alarms. 
( Ord. No. 14-03 , § 1, 10-9-2014) 
Sec. 7-138. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Notice of the right of appeal under this article shall be included with any fines. 
(b)  User fines: 
(1)  It is hereby found and determined that three or more false alarms within an alarm site's 12-month registration period is excessive, constitutes a public nuisance and shall be unlawful. 
(2)  Civil penalties for false alarms within an alarm site's 12-month registration period may be assessed against an alarm user as follows: 
a.  First and second false alarms ..... No fine. 
b.  Third false alarm ..... $50.00 
c.  Fourth, fifth, sixth and seventh false alarms ..... $100.00 
      per false alarm 
d.  Eighth false alarm ..... $100.00 
      per false alarm and placed on restricted response. 
e.  Ninth and over false alarm (if reinstated) ..... $500.00 
      per false alarm and placed on restricted response. 
f.  False alarm at an unregistered alarm site ..... $50.00 
      per false alarm and placed on restricted response after 30 days from the alarm response date. 
(3)  If cancellation of an alarm dispatch request occurs prior to the police arriving at the alarm site, no false alarm will be assessed. 
(4)  The $50.00 fine for a false alarm at an unregistered alarm site may be waived by the alarm administrator if the alarm user obtains a permit within 30 days of the false alarm. 
(c)  Alarm monitoring company: 
(1)  An alarm monitoring company shall be issued a fine of $250.00 for requesting a police dispatch to an alarm site that has been placed on restricted response and the alarm monitoring company did not obtain verification that a crime is being or has been committed. The alarm administrator will notify the monitoring company when the alarm site is placed on restricted response. 
(d)  Restricted response: 
(1)  The alarm administrator may place an alarm site on restricted response status if it is determined that: 
a.  The alarm user has eight or more false alarms during the alarm site's 12-month registration period; 
b.  There is a statement of a material fact known to be false in the application for a registration; 
c.  The alarm user has failed to make payment after 90 days of a fine or fee assessed under this article; 
d.  The alarm user has failed to submit a written certification from an alarm installation or servicing company, that complies with the requirements of this article, stating that the alarm system has been inspected and repaired (if necessary) and/or additional training has been conducted by the alarm installation or servicing company; 
e.  The alarm user has refused to comply with the registration requirement 30 days after being notified by the alarm administrator of the requirement. 
(2)  Unless there is verification through an eye-witness or audio or visual monitoring that a crime has been or is being committed at the alarm site, the Roswell Police Department will refuse response to an alarm site that has been placed on restricted response. 
(3)  The restricted response status will remain in effect until the alarm user eliminates the problem of excessive false alarms at the alarm site, pays any outstanding fees and fines or corrects any violation of this article. 
(4)  If the alarm site is reinstated from restricted response pursuant to this article, the alarm administrator may again place the alarm site on restricted response if it is determined that false alarms are continuing at the alarm site. 
(5)  A police supervisor may refuse law enforcement response to an alarm site during the duration of the supervisor's shift when there has been two or more police dispatch requests to the alarm site in a 24-hour period and the alarm user cannot be contacted to take corrective action. 
( Ord. No. 14-03 , § 1, 10-9-2014) 
Sec. 7-139. - Appeals. 
(a)  If the alarm administrator assesses a fine or denies the issuance, renewal or reinstatement of an alarm registration, the alarm administrator shall send written notice of the action and a statement of the right to an appeal to the alarm user and the alarm installation or servicing company and/or alarm monitoring company. 
(b)  The alarm user, alarm installation or servicing company or alarm monitoring company may appeal an assessment of a fine or the revocation of an alarm registration to the alarm administrator by setting forth in writing the reasons for the appeal within 20 business days after notice of the fine or of revocation. 
(c)  The alarm user or the alarm installation or servicing company or alarm monitoring company may appeal the decision of the alarm administrator to the Roswell Police Department Chief of Police as follows: 
(1)  The first level of appeal is for the affected alarm user, alarm installation or servicing company or alarm monitoring company to contact the alarms administrator to discuss the grievance. The affected party will inform the alarms administrator the reasons he or she disagrees with the initial decision of the alarms administrator. The alarms administrator may affirm, modify or reverse the initial decision based on the affected party's information. The alarms administrator has the authority to waive any fines and fees, change the alarm permit status and delete false alarm records from alarm permits. 
(2)  If the affected party is not satisfied with the decision of the alarms administrator, the applicant may file a written request for a review by the Roswell Police Department Chief of Police through the alarms administration office by paying an appeal fee of $25.00 and setting forth the reasons for the appeal within 20 business days after the date of notification of the decision from the alarm administrator. 
(3)  The chief of police or his designee shall conduct a review within 30 days of the receipt of the request and consider the evidence by any interested person(s). 
(4)  The chief of police or his designee shall make a decision based on the evidence presented at the hearing. 
(5)  The chief of police or his designee must render a decision within ten days after the date of the hearing. The chief of police or his designee will affirm, modify or reverse the decision of the alarm administrator. 
(d)  Filing of a request for appeal shall stay the action by the alarm administrator until the chief of police or his designee has completed its review. If a request for appeal is not made within the 20-business-day period, the action of the alarm administrator is final. 
(e)  Alarm administrator or the chief of police may adjust the count of false alarms based on: 
(1)  Evidence that a false alarm was caused by severe weather conditions. 
(2)  Evidence that a false alarm was caused by a power outage lasting longer than four hours; 
(3)  Evidence that the alarm dispatch request was not a false alarm; 
(4)  Malicious causes beyond the control of the alarm user; 
(5)  In determining the number of false alarms, multiple alarms occurring in any 24-hour period shall be counted as one false alarm; to allow the alarm user time to take corrective action unless the false alarms are directly caused by the alarm user. 
( Ord. No. 14-03 , § 1, 10-9-2014) 
Sec. 7-140. - Reinstatement. 
(a)  A person whose alarm registration has been placed on restricted response status may, at the discretion of the alarm administrator, have the alarm registration reinstated if the person: 
(1)  Pays, or otherwise resolves, all outstanding citations and fines; and 
(2)  Provides satisfactory evidence to the alarm administrator that the alarm system has been inspected and repaired (if necessary) by the alarm installation or servicing company; and/or that additional training in the proper use of the alarm system has been provided by the alarm installation or servicing company for all alarm users. 
(b)  In addition, the alarm administrator may require one or more of the following as a condition to reinstatement: 
(1)  Proof that an employee of the alarm installation or servicing company or alarm monitoring company caused the false alarm; 
(2)  A certificate showing that the alarm user has successfully completed the alarm user awareness class; 
(3)  Evidence that the alarm control panel has been upgraded to meet ANSI/SIA control panel standard CPOl; 
(4)  A written statement from an independent inspector designated by the alarm administrator that the alarm system has been inspected and is in good working order; 
(5)  Confirmation that all motion detectors are "dual technology" type; 
(6)  Confirmation that the alarm monitoring company will not make an alarm dispatch request unless the need for public safety is confirmed by audio or video verification; 
(7)  Confirmation that the alarm monitoring company will not make an alarm dispatch request unless the need for public safety is confirmed by a person at the alarm site. 
( Ord. No. 14-03 , § 1, 10-9-2014) 
Sec. 7-141. - Confidentiality. 
    In the interest of public safety, all information contained in and gathered through the alarm registration applications, records relating to alarm dispatch requests, and applications for appeals shall be held in confidence by all employees or representatives of the municipality and by any third-party administrator or employees of a third-party administrator with access to such information. 
( Ord. No. 14-03 , § 1, 10-9-2014) 
Sec. 7-142. - Government immunity. 
    Alarm registration is not intended to, nor will it, create a contract, duty or obligation, either expressed or implied, of response. Any and all liability and consequential damage resulting from the failure to respond to a notification is hereby disclaimed and governmental immunity as provided by law is retained. By applying for an alarm registration, the alarm user acknowledges that public safety response may be influenced by factors such as: the availability of public safety units, priority of calls, weather conditions, traffic conditions, emergency conditions, staffing levels and prior response history. 
( Ord. No. 14-03 , § 1, 10-9-2014) 
ARTICLE XI. - CASUAL SALES OF MOTOR VEHICLES 

Sec. 7-143. - Purpose and application. 
    In recognition of the fact that the active trade or business of engaging in the sale of motor vehicles and engaging in the operation of a business within the City of Roswell affects a public interest on behalf of the safety and welfare of the community and the city has a substantial interest in ensuring that such business is conducted pursuant to the regulations of the City of Roswell and the laws of New Mexico, this chapter is adopted and shall be construed liberally. 
    This article does not apply to or prohibit the sale of vehicles by: 
(1)  Dealers; 
(2)  Receivers, trustees, administrators, executors, guardians or other persons appointed by or acting under judgment, decree or order of any court; 
(3)  Public officers while performing their duties as such officers; 
(4)  Finance companies, banks and other lending institutions making sales of repossessed vehicles; or 
(5)  Licensed brokers under the Manufactured Housing Act who, for a fee, commission or other valuable consideration, engage in brokerage activities related to the sale, exchange or lease purchase of pre-owned manufactured homes on a site installed by a consumer. 
( Ord. No. 13-07 , § 1, 4-11-2013) 
Sec. 7-144. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Casual sale means the sale of a motor vehicle by the registered owner or owner's agent of the vehicle, who is not a registered dealer, if the owner has not sold more than four vehicles in that calendar year. 
    Dealer means any person who sells or solicits or advertises the sale of new or used motor vehicles, manufactured homes or trailers subject to registration in this state, who is licensed or certified by the State of New Mexico as a dealer. The term dealer does not include: 
(1)  Receivers, trustees, administrators, executors, guardians or other persons appointed by or acting under judgment, decree or order of any court; 
(2)  Public officers while performing their duties as such officers; 
(3)  Persons making casual sales of their own vehicles; 
(4)  Finance companies, banks and other lending institutions making sales of repossessed vehicles; or 
(5)  Licensed brokers under the Manufactured Housing Act who, for a fee, commission or other valuable consideration, engage in brokerage activities related to the sale, exchange or lease purchase of pre-owned manufactured homes on a site installed by a consumer. 
    Motor vehicle means every vehicle that is self-propelled and every vehicle that is propelled by electric power obtained from batteries or from overhead trolley wires, but not operated upon rails. 
( Ord. No. 13-07 , § 1, 4-11-2013) 
Sec. 7-145. - Notice to city. 
    No person shall engage in the casual sale of a motor vehicle within the City of Roswell unless that person is a resident of Chaves County, New Mexico, and without first filing with the business licensing clerk for the City of Roswell a written notice giving the following information, and receiving a permit from the clerk. There shall be no charge for the permit. 
(1)  His name and address; 
(2)  The location where the casual sale of the motor vehicle is to be held; 
(3)  The date of the commencement of the sale and the date of the termination of the sale, if any; 
(4)  An acknowledgment that the seller has not conducted more than four casual sales of motor vehicles during the current calendar year; 
(5)  The seller acknowledges his liability for payment to the state of gross receipts tax upon the proceeds of any such sale; 
(6)  A copy of the registration for the vehicle which shows the person is the registered owner of the vehicle or documents demonstrating the person is entitled to sell the vehicle, and; 
(7)  If the vehicle will be sold on property that is not owned by the person, written permission from the owner or tenant to sell the vehicle at that location. 
( Ord. No. 13-07 , § 1, 4-11-2013) 
Sec. 7-146. - Business license required. 
    Any dealer proposing to engage in business or the selling motor vehicles of services within the city limits of the City of Roswell shall apply for and pay a business registration fee for each outlet, branch or location or place of business within the city prior to engaging in business. 
( Ord. No. 13-07 , § 1, 4-11-2013) 
Sec. 7-147. - Frequency. 
    No person shall conduct the casual sale of a motor vehicle within the city limits of the City of Roswell more than four times during a calendar year without obtaining a dealer's license as required by the laws of the State of New Mexico. 
( Ord. No. 13-07 , § 1, 4-11-2013) 
Sec. 7-148. - Posting the permit. 
    No person shall engage in the casual sale of a motor vehicle within the city limits of the City of Roswell without a permit from the City of Roswell, a copy of which shall be posted in a conspicuous location on or in the motor vehicle being sold in such a manner which allows for the permit to be seen at least 20 feet from the vehicle. 
( Ord. No. 13-07 , § 1, 4-11-2013) 
Sec. 7-149. - Penalty. 
    Except as herein otherwise provided, any person who willfully or intentionally or unlawfully conducts a sale of a vehicle in violation of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
( Ord. No. 13-07 , § 1, 4-11-2013) 
Secs. 7-150-7-159. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - BODY ART SAFE PRACTICES 

Sec. 7-160. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following definitions shall apply: 
    Body art shall be defined as the same term is defined in the "Body Art Safe Practices Act" (NMSA 1978 § 61-17B-1 et seq.) and the state regulations adopted pursuant thereto. 
    Body art means tattooing, body piercing or scarification but does not include practices that are considered medical procedures by the New Mexico medical board. 
    Body art establishment means a fixed place of business where body art is administered on the premises. 
    Body artist means a person who administers body piercing, tattooing or scarification. 
    Body Art Safe Practices Act , means the provisions of the New Mexico Body Art Safe Practices Act as codified under Article 17B of Chapter 61 of the New Mexico Statutes Annotated, 1978 Compilation, as may be amended or revised, together with any rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto. 
    Body piercing means to cut, stab or penetrate the skin to create a permanent hole or opening. 
    Operator means the owner in charge of a body art establishment. 
    Scarification means cutting into the skin with a sharp instrument or branding the skin with a heated instrument to produce a permanent mark or design on the skin. 
    Tattooing means the practice of depositing pigment, which is either permanent, semi-permanent or temporary, into the epidermis using needles by a person other than a state-licensed physician or a person under the supervision of a state-licensed physician and includes permanent cosmetics, dermography, micropigmentation, permanent color technology and micro-pigment implantation. 
(Ord. No, 17-01 , § 1, 2-9-2017) 
Sec. 7-161. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this ordinance is to ensure that the minimum standards for safe body art practices occur in the city by providing for business licensing of body art establishments at the local governmental level, and to provide more stringent standards for safe body art practices as the governing body may deem appropriate for the protection of the public. 
(Ord. No, 17-01 , § 1, 2-9-2017) 
Sec. 7-162. - Business license; compliance with the New Mexico Body Art Safe Practices Act. 
(a)  All applicants wishing to operate a body art establishment must, prior to engaging in such business, pay to the City of Roswell the business license fee as set forth in the Roswell City Code, chapter 7, article II, and must demonstrate and show proof that: 
(1)  The applicant has been issued a current and valid body art operator license from the state of New Mexico under the provisions of the Body Arts Safe Practices Act; and that 
(2)  Each body artist working at the body art establishment has been issued a current and valid body art license from the state of New Mexico under the provisions of the Body Arts Safe Practices Act. 
(b)  Each individual applicant wishing to engage in the business of body art must, prior to engaging in such business, pay to the City of Roswell the business license fee as set forth in the Roswell City Code, chapter 7, article II, and must demonstrate and show proof that the applicant has been issued a current and valid body art license from the state of New Mexico under the provisions of the Body Arts Safe Practices Act. 
(c)  Prior to receiving an annual renewal of the business license for a body art establishment, each operator must provide evidence to the city clerk that the body art establishment successfully passed the most recent state inspection, provided the last inspection was within the past 24 months, pursuant to the Body Art Safe Practices. In the event that the body art establishment has not been inspected by the state through no fault of the operator, the operator may apply to the city council for an extension of time allowing the business to operate temporarily until an inspection can be performed. 
(d)  Business licenses for body art establishments shall be non-transferable. 
(e)  An operator shall not change the location of the body art establishment location within the city without the prior approval of the city. 
(Ord. No, 17-01 , § 1, 2-9-2017) 
Sec. 7-163. - Prohibitions; standards of practice. 
(a)  The following are prohibited under this article: 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to administer body art without a valid state body art license as required by law under this article. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a body art establishment without a valid state operator's license and a license under this article. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful for any person to administer body art in any place other than a duly licensed body art establishment under this article. 
(4)  No person shall administer body art unless that person shall possess a body art license from the state board which shall not have been suspended or expired and a license under this article. 
(5)  No operator shall permit any person to administer body art in said operator's body art establishment unless that person possesses a valid and unsuspended license issued by the state and a license under this article. 
(6)  A body art establishment constitutes a prohibited home occupation under the provisions of the Roswell Zoning Ordinance (article 28, section 4, subsection 2) as a body piercing or tattoo shop. 
(7)  No person shall perform or engage in the business of body art unless that person shall have obtained a current and valid body art license from the State of New Mexico and a business licenses from the city. 
(b)  All body artists and operators shall adhere to the requirements and standards of practice as established in the New Mexico Body Arts Safe Practices Act, NMSA 1978, §§ 61-17B-1-61-17B-18, and the regulations adopted by the Board of Body Art Practioners, NMAC 16.36.1-6. Failure to follow those requirements shall be a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No, 17-01 , § 1, 2-9-2017) 
Sec. 7-164. - Minors. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any owner, manager or other person in charge of a body art establishment to administer body art on any person under the age of 18 unless accompanied by a parent or legal guardian who signs a written statement consenting to the body art. Proof of age shall be demonstrated by a government-issued photo identification accompanied by at least one other government-issued document showing proof of age, such as a birth certificate. 
(b)  Each body art establishment shall maintain a record of all consent forms signed on behalf of a person under 18 and shall be able to present those forms upon request during an inspection by code enforcement. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any owner, manager or other person in charge of a body art establishment to knowingly allow a person under the age of 18 to be admitted into a body art establishment unless accompanied by a parent or legal guardian. 
(Ord. No, 17-01 , § 1, 2-9-2017) 
Sec. 7-165. - State inspections. 
    If a body art establishment fails to successfully pass a state board inspection, the body art establishment shall suspend body art activities until such time as the state conducts a re-inspection and the body art establishment passes the inspection or satisfies any deficiency from the prior inspection. 
(Ord. No, 17-01 , § 1, 2-9-2017) 
Sec. 7-166. - Inspections. 
(a)  The Code Enforcement Division shall annually inspect body art establishments to determine compliance with the provisions of this ordinance and the Body Arts Safe Practices Act. 
(b)  An operator or body artist shall allow a city code enforcement official, upon proper identification, to enter the licensed premises, to inspect all parts of the licensed premises, and upon request, shall provide proof of all licenses and documents, including parental consent forms, as required by City Code. 
(c)  A code enforcement officer may confirm the identity and license status of each artist by examining a government-issued identification upon request. 
(d)  The operator or body artist shall be given an opportunity to accompany the code enforcement official on the inspection and to receive a report of the inspection within 14 days after the inspection. 
(e)  Refusal to allow an inspection is grounds for suspension or revocation of the business license issued under this ordinance, provided that the code enforcement official tendered proper identification prior to refusal. 
(f)  The following information shall be kept on file at the location of where a body art establishment licensed: state operator's license, city business license, and licenses for all body artists working in the body art establishment. 
(Ord. No, 17-01 , § 1, 2-9-2017) 
Sec. 7-167. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this ordinance shall not apply to any person who is exempt from the requirements of the New Mexico Body Art Safe Practices Act, NMSA 1978, § 61-17B-7, as specified below or as otherwise amended: 
(1)  A person who pierces only the outer perimeter of the ear, not including any cartilage, using a pre-sterilized encapsulated single use stud ear piercing system, implementing appropriate procedures, is exempt from the requirements of the New Mexico Body Art Safe Practices Act. 
(2)  A member of a federally recognized tribe, band, nation or pueblo who performs scarification rituals for religious purposes is exempt from the requirements of the New Mexico Body Art Safe Practices Act. 
(Ord. No, 17-01 , § 1, 2-9-2017) 
Sec. 7-168. - Penalties. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for anyone to administer body art without a state and city license as required by law under this section or for anyone to administer body art in any place other than a duly licensed body art establishment. Upon conviction of a violation of this subsection, the municipal court shall impose, in addition to any other penalty, a mandatory fine of $500.00 per occurrence. 
(b)  Persons violating any other provision of this article shall be punished as provided in section 15-12 of the Roswell City Code. 
(Ord. No, 17-01 , § 1, 2-9-2017) 
Chapter 8 - CAMPING AND CAMPGROUNDS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-1. - Erection of tents, etc. 
(a)  No tents, canvas or paper structures or buildings partly of boards and tenting or other like camping material shall be constructed or allowed within the city for living purposes. 
(b)  No owner, agent or occupant of any lot, piece or parcel of land shall permit any person to construct, erect or use tents upon his property within the city in violation of this section. 
(Code 1962 § 2-60) 
Secs. 8-2-8-5. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CAMPGROUNDS 

Sec. 8-6. - Enforcement. 
    It shall be the duty of the building inspector to inspect all campgrounds and to enforce this article. 
(Code 1984 § 8-16) 
Sec. 8-7. - Use required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to camp within the city unless he camps within a campground which has been issued a business registration by the city. 
(Code 1984 § 8-17) 
Cross reference- Business registration, § 7-6 et seq. 
Sec. 8-8. - Sanitary regulations. 
(a)  Any person owning, operating or maintaining any campground in the city shall comply with the following provisions: 
(1)  Water flush toilets shall be provided, and shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(2)  Equipment sufficient to prevent littering of the campground with rubbish, garbage or other refuse shall be provided, maintained and supervised, and flytight depositories for such materials shall be provided and conspicuously located. 
(3)  All water used in the campground shall be pure and free from all impurities and fit for human consumption. 
(4)  A thorough clean-up shall be made of the campground every 24 hours. 
(b)  Each person owning, operating or maintaining a campground shall be held responsible for compliance with this section. 
(Code 1984 § 8-18) 
State Law reference- Power of city to legislate for public health, safety and welfare, NMSA 1978, § 3-18-1. 
Cross reference- Business registration, § 7-6 et seq.; lodging tax, § 24-1 et seq.; parks and recreation, ch. 17. 
Sec. 8-9. - Owner's register. 
    The owner or operator of any campground shall keep a register in which they shall require all persons using their grounds to register their names, home address and number of their car. 
(Code 1984 § 8-19) 
Chapter 9 - CEMETERIES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 9-1-9-5. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MUNICIPAL CEMETERY 

Sec. 9-6. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Board means the Cemetery Board of Roswell, as established by the Roswell City Code. 
    Municipal cemetery means the municipal cemetery of the city. 
    Sexton means the administrative superintendent of the cemetery. 
    Year means the calendar year period from July 1 to and including June 30 of the following year. 
(Code 1984 § 1-16; Ord. No. 04-11, 7-2004) 
Sec. 9-7. - Cemetery board. 
    The cemetery board shall be the advisory board created by the Roswell City Code and shall not have or exercise the power and authority of the cemetery board allowed by state law. 
(Ord. 04-11, 7-2004) 
State Law reference- Municipal cemetery boards, NMSA 1978, § 3-40-1 et seq. 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions generally, § 2-96 et seq. 
Sec. 9-8. - Sale of burial lots. 
    The city shall have the power to sell any burial lot within the municipal cemetery and to exercise such powers provided by law for municipal cemeteries. 
(Code 1984 § 9-18) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority relative to cemeteries, NMSA 1978, § 3-18-8; Endowed Care Cemetery Act of 1961, NMSA § 58-17-1 et seq.; Municipal authority to establish, maintain, etc., cemeteries, NMSA 1978, § 3-40-1. 
Sec. 9-9. - Violations of cemetery regulations. 
    It is unlawful to violate the regulations promulgated and approved by the governing body. 
(Code 1984 § 9-19; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999; Ord. No. 04-11, 7-2004) 
Chapter 10 - CRIMINAL OFFENSES 
ARTICLE I. - ASSAULT AND BATTERY 

Sec. 10-1. - Assault. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit assault, consisting of either: 
(1)  An attempt to commit a battery upon the person of another; 
(2)  Any unlawful act, threat or menacing conduct which causes another person to reasonably believe that he is in danger of receiving an immediate battery; or 
(3)  The use of insulting language toward another impugning his honor, delicacy or reputation. 
(Code 1984 § 16-1) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 30-3-1. 
Sec. 10-2. - Assault against a household member. 
(a)  Household member means a spouse, former spouse or family member, including a relative, parent, present or former step-parent, present or former in-law, a co-parent of a child or a person with whom a person has had a continuing personal relationship. Cohabitation is not necessary to be deemed a household member. 
(b)  Assault against a household member consists of: 
(1)  An attempt to commit a battery against a household member; or 
(2)  Any unlawful act, threat or menacing conduct that causes a household member to reasonably believe that he is in danger of receiving an immediate battery. 
(c)  It is unlawful to commit assault against a household member. 
(Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999; Ord. No. 00-7, § 3, 9-2000) 
Sec. 10-3. - Battery. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit battery, consisting of the unlawful, intentional touching or application of force to the person of another, when done in a rude, insolent or angry manner. 
(Code 1984 § 16-3) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 30-3-4. 
Sec. 10-4. - Battery against a household member. 
(a)  Battery against a household member (household member is defined in section 10-2) consists of the unlawful, intentional touching or application of force to the person of a household member, when done in a rude, insolent or angry manner. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to commit battery against a household member. 
(Ord. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 10-5. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DRUG OFFENSES 

Sec. 10-6. - Possession of marijuana. 
(a)  As used in this section, the term marijuana means all parts of the plant Cannabis, including any and all varieties, species and subspecies of the genus Cannabis, whether growing or not, the seeds thereof, and every compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture or preparation of the plant or its seeds. The term does not include the mature stalks of the plant, hashish, tetrahydrocannabinol extracted or isolated from marijuana, fiber produced from the stalks, oil or cake made from the seeds of the plant, any other compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture or preparation of the mature stalks, fiber, oil or cake, or the sterilized seed of the plant which is incapable of germination. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person intentionally to possess marijuana unless it was obtained pursuant to a valid prescription or order of a practitioner while acting in the course of his professional practice or except as otherwise authorized by law. 
(c)  A person convicted for violation of subsection (b) of this section shall be assessed, in addition to any other fine or fee, a fee of $75.00 to defray the costs of chemical or other analyses of controlled substances. 
(d)  Fees collected hereunder shall be transmitted to the administrative office of the courts, as provided by NMSA 1978, 31-12-9. 
(Code 1984 § 22-15 ) 
State Law reference- Controlled substances, NMSA 1978, § 30-31-1 et seq. 
Sec. 10-7. - Possession of drug paraphernalia. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to use or possess with intent to use drug paraphernalia to plant, propagate, cultivate, grow, harvest, manufacture, compound, convert, produce, process, prepare, test, analyze, pack, repack, store, contain, conceal, inject, ingest, inhale or otherwise introduce into the human body a controlled substance in violation of the New Mexico controlled Substances Act. The provisions of this subsection do not apply to a person who is in possession of hypodermic syringes or needles at the time he is directly and immediately engaged in a harm reduction program, as provided in state law. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person to deliver, possess with intent to deliver or manufacture with the intent to deliver drug paraphernalia with knowledge, or under circumstances where one reasonably should know, that it will be used to plant, propagate, cultivate, grow, harvest, manufacture, compound, convert, produce, process, prepare, test, analyze, pack, repack, store, contain, conceal, inject, ingest, inhale or otherwise introduce into the human body a controlled substance in violation of the New Mexico Controlled Substances Act. The provisions of this subsection do not apply to New Mexico state employees or their designees while they are directly and immediately engaged in activities related to the harm reduction program authorized by state law. 
(Ord. 1320, 4-1999) 
Secs. 10-8-10-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - GAMBLING 

Sec. 10-11. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bet means a bargain in which the parties agree that, dependent upon chance, even though accompanied by some skill, one stands to win or lose anything of value specified in the agreement. A bet does not include: 
(1)  Bona fide business transactions which are valid under the law of contracts, including, without limitation: 
a.  Contracts for the purchase or sale, at a future date, of securities or other commodities; and 
b.  Agreements to compensate for loss caused by the happening of the chance, including, without limitation, contracts for indemnity or guaranty and life or health and accident insurance. 
(2)  Offers of purses, prizes or premiums to actual contestants in any bona fide contest for the determination of skill, speed, strength or endurance or the bona fide owner of animals or vehicles entered in such contests. 
(3)  A lottery. 
(4)  Betting otherwise permitted by law. 
    Lottery means an enterprise wherein, for a consideration, the participants are given an opportunity to win a prize, the award of which is determined by chance, even though accompanied by some skill. As used in this definition, "consideration" means anything of pecuniary value required to he paid to the promoter in order to participate in such enterprise. 
    Gambling device means a contrivance which, for a consideration affords the player an opportunity to obtain anything of value, the award of which is determined by chance, even though accompanied by some skill and whether or not the prize is automatically paid by the device. 
    Gambling place means any building or tent, any vehicle whether self-propelled or not, or any room within any of them, one of whose principal uses is: 
(1)  Making and settling of bets. 
(2)  Receiving, holding, recording or forwarding bets or offers to bet. 
(3)  Conducting lotteries. 
(4)  Playing gambling devices. 
(Code 1984 § 16-51) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 30-19-1. 
Sec. 10-12. - Prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit gambling, consisting of: 
(1)  Making a bet; 
(2)  Entering or remaining in a gambling place with intent to make a bet, to a lottery or to play a gambling device; 
(3)  Conducting a lottery; or 
(4)  Possessing facilities with intent to conduct a lottery. 
(Code 1984 § 16-52) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 30-19-2. 
Sec. 10-13. - Permitting premises to be used for gambling. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit permitting premises to be used for gambling, consisting of: 
(1)  Knowingly permitting any property owned or occupied by such person or under his control to be used as a gambling place; or 
(2)  Knowingly permitting a gambling device to be set up for the purpose of gambling in a place under his control. 
(Code 1984 § 16-53) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 30-19-4. 
Sec. 10-14. - Permissive lottery. 
(a)  Nothing in this article shall be construed to apply to any sale or drawing of any prize at any fair held in this state for the benefit of any church, public library or religious society situated or being in this state, or for charitable purposes when all the proceeds of such fair shall be expended in this state for the benefit of such church, public library, religious society or charitable purposes. 
    A lottery shall be operated for the benefit of the organization or charitable purpose only when the entire proceeds of the lottery go to the organization or charitable purpose and no part of such proceeds go to any individual member or employee thereof. 
(b)  Nothing in this article shall be held to prohibit any bona fide motion picture theater from offering prizes of cash or merchandise for advertising purposes, in connection with such business, or for the purpose of stimulating business, whether or not any consideration other than a monetary consideration in excess of the regular price of admission is exacted for participation in drawings for prizes. 
(c)  Nothing in this article shall be held to apply to any bona fide county fair, including fairs for more than one county, which shall have been held annually at the same location for at least two years and which shall offer prizes of livestock or poultry in connection with such fair when the proceeds of such drawings shall be used for the benefit of said fair. 
(d)  Nothing in this article shall be construed to apply to any lottery operated by an organization exempt from the state income tax pursuant to NMSA 1978, § 7-2-4B, and not subject to the provisions of subsection (a) of this section; provided that: 
(1)  No more than two lotteries shall be operated in any year by such an organization; 
(2)  All the gross proceeds less the reasonable cost of prizes of any lottery operated by such an organization shall be expended in the state for the benefit of the organization or public purposes; and 
(3)  No part of the proceeds of any lottery shall go to any individual member or employee of any organization except as payment for the purchase of prizes at no more than the reasonable retail price. 
(e)  Nothing in this article shall be construed to apply to any lottery operated by the State of New Mexico. 
(Code 1984 § 16-54; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions. NMSA 1978, § 30-19-6. 
Sec. 10-15. - Gambling devices and gambling houses as public nuisance. 
    Except as otherwise permitted or excepted hereunder, any gambling device or gambling place is a public nuisance per se and may be abated as provided by law. 
(Code 1984 § 16-55) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 30-19-8. 
Secs. 10-16-10-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - LARCENY AND RELATED OFFENSES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-21. - Larceny. 
(a)  Anything of value. Any conceivable thing of the slightest value, tangible or intangible, movable or immovable, corporeal or incorporeal, public or private. The term is not necessarily synonymous with the traditional legal term "property." Definition applies to all the sections in this article as applicable. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to commit larceny, consisting of the stealing of anything of value of $250.00 or less. 
(Code 1984 § 16-81; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999; Ord. No. 07-02, 9-2007) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 30-16-1. 
Sec. 10-22. - Fraud. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit fraud, consisting of the intentional misappropriation or taking of anything of value of $250.00 or less, which belongs to another by means of fraudulent conduct, practices or representations. 
(Code 1984 § 16-82; Ord. No. 07-02, 9-2007) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 30-16-6. 
Editor's note- Includes fraud by worthless check. 
Sec. 10-23. - Embezzlement. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit embezzlement, consisting of converting to his own use of anything of value of $250.00 or less, with which he has been entrusted, with fraudulent intent to deprive the owner thereof. 
(Code 1984 § 16-83; Ord. No. 07-02, 9-2007)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 30-16-8. 
Sec. 10-24. - Receiving stolen property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit receiving stolen property, consisting of buying, procuring, receiving or concealing anything of value of $250.00 or less knowing the same to have been stolen or acquired by fraud or embezzlement. 
(Code 1984 § 16-84; Ord. No. 07-02, 9-2007) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 30-16-11 
Sec. 10-25. - Falsely representing self as incapacitated. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit falsely representing self as incapacitated, consisting of falsely representing himself to be blind, deaf, dumb, crippled or otherwise physically defective for the purpose of obtaining money or other thing of value. 
(Code 1984 § 16-85) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 30-16.12. 
Sec. 10-26. - Cheating machine or device. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit cheating machine or device, consisting of attempting to operate or causing to be operated any automatic vending machine, parking meter, coin box telephone or any machine or receptacle designed to receive lawful money of the United States in the connection with the sale, use or enjoyment of property or service, by means of any slug, or by a false, counterfeited, sweated or foreign coin, or by any means, method, trick or device. 
(Code 1984 § 16-86) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 30-16-13. 
Sec. 10-27. - Falsely obtaining services or accommodations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit falsely obtaining services or accommodations, consisting of obtaining any service, food, entertainment or accommodations of the value of $250.00 or less, without paying therefor, and with intent to cheat or defraud the owner or person supplying such service, food, entertainment or accommodations. 
(Code 1984 § 16-87; Ord. No. 07-02, 9-2007) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 30-16-10. 
Sec. 10-28. - Unlawful removal of effects. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit unlawful removal of effects, consisting of removing or causing to be removed any baggage or effects from any hotel, motel, trailer park, inn, rented dwelling or boarding house while there is a lien existing thereon for proper and lawful charge due for fare or board furnished by or from such hotel, motel, trailer park, inn, rented dwelling or boarding house, and where the owner or person in possession of such baggage or effects is given actual notice of the fact of such lien, or where a notice of such lien is conspicuously posted upon the premises adjacent to such baggage or effects, giving notice of the fact of such lien and the amount thereof. 
(Code 1984 § 16-886) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 30-16-17. 
Sec. 10-29. - Unauthorized obtaining and use of cable television transmissions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, partnership, or corporation to attach or connect, or cause to be attached or connected, to a television transmission, any device, mechanism or conductor that carries, intercepts, receives, decodes, converts or descrambles the cable television signals and transmissions of the permittee, without the permission or authorization of said permittee; provided however that before a prosecution can be commenced under this subsection, the permittee shall notify such person, partnership, or corporation that such attachments or connection have been made without the authorization of the permittee, and further, that unless such person, partnership or corporation ceases such unauthorized attachments or connections within five days, a prosecution will be commenced under this subsection. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, partnership, corporation to receive cable television signals or transmissions on a television set or other equipment designed to receive a television transmission to which has been attached a device that carries, intercepts, receives, decodes, converts, or descrambles the cable television signal or transmission without the express permission or authorization of said permittee; provided, however, that before a prosecution can be commenced under this subsection, the permittee shall notify such person, partnership, or corporation that such signal or transmission is being received without the authorization of the permittee and, further, that unless such person, partnership or corporation ceases such unauthorized use within five days, a prosecution will be commenced under this subsection. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person, partnership or corporation to remove, modify or tamper with any trap, converter, decoder, or device installed by the permittee in order to received service without the permission or authorization of the permittee. 
(d)  Any such illegal acts of subsections (a), (b) or (c) shall constitute a petty misdemeanor and shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed $300.00 or a jail sentence not to exceed 90 days, or both such fine and imprisonment. 
(e)  Provisions of subsections (a), (b), (c), and (d) hereby shall not be held to apply to broadcast signals. 
(Ord. No. 1116, 2-1984; Ord. No. 07-02, 9-2007) 
Sec. 10-30. - Fraudulent use of a credit card. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit fraudulent use of a credit card, consisting of a person obtaining anything of value of $250.00 or less, with the intent to defraud by using one or more of the following. 
(1)  A credit card while fraudulently representing that the person is the cardholder named on the credit card or an authorized agent or representative of the cardholder named on the credit card; or 
(2)  A credit card issued in the name of another person without the consent of the person to whom the card has been issued. 
(Ord. No. 10-06, 11-2010) 
Sec. 10-31. - Possession of a credit card stolen, lost, mislaid, or delivered by mistake. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person other than the issuer who receives or possesses a credit card that he knows or has reason to know it to have been stolen, lost, mislaid or delivered under a mistake as to the identity or address of the cardholder, and who retains possession thereof with the intent to use it or to sell it or to transfer it to a person other than the issuer or the cardholder. 
(Ord. No. 10-07, 11-2010) 
Sec. 10-32. - Issuance of worthless check. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to issue in exchange for anything of value of $250.00 or less, with intent to defraud, any check, draft or order for payment of money upon any bank or other depository, knowing at the time of the issuing that the offender has insufficient funds in or credit with the bank or depository for the payment of such check, draft or order in full upon its presentation. 
(Ord. No. 10-08, 11-2010) 
Secs. 10-33-10-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SHOPLIFTING 

Sec. 10-41. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Merchandise means chattels of any type or description offered for sale in or about a store when the value of the merchandise shoplifted is not more than $250.00. 
    Merchant means any owner or proprietor of any store, or any agent, servant or employee of the owner or proprietor. 
    Store means a place where merchandise is sold or offered to the public for sale at retail. 
(Code 1984 § 16-101; Ord. No. 07-02, 9-2007) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 30-16-19. 
Sec. 10-42. - Prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to commit shoplifting, consisting of any one or more of the following acts: 
(1)  Willfully taking possession of any merchandise of a value of $250.00 or less with the intention of converting it without paying for it. 
(2)  Willfully concealing any merchandise of a value of $250.00 or less with the intention of converting it without paying for it. 
(3)  Willfully altering any label, price tag or marking upon any merchandise of a value of $250.00 or less with the intention of depriving the merchant of all or some part of the value of it. 
(4)  Willfully transferring any merchandise of a value of $250.00 or less from the container in or on which it is displayed to any other container with the intention of depriving the merchant of all or some part of the value of it. 
(b)  Any person charged with a violation of this section shall not be charged with a separate or additional offense arising out of the same transaction. 
(Code 1984 § 16-102; Ord. No. 07-02, 9-2007) 
Sec. 10-43. - Presumptions. 
    Any person who willfully conceals merchandise on his person or on the person of another or among his belongings or the belongings of another or on or outside the premises of the store shall be prima facie presumed to have concealed the merchandise with the intention of converting it without paying for it. If any merchandise is found concealed upon any person or among his belongings, it shall be prima facie evidence of willful concealment. 
(Code 1984 § 16-103; Ord. No. 00-7, § 3, 9-2000) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 30-16-22. 
Sec. 10-44. - Detention of suspects. 
(a)  If any law enforcement officer, special officer or merchant has probable cause for believing that a person has willfully taken possession of any merchandise with the intention of converting it without paying for it, or has willfully concealed merchandise, and that he can recover the merchandise by detaining the person or taking him into custody, the law enforcement officer, special officer or merchant may, for the purpose of attempting to effect a recovery of the merchandise, take the person into custody and detain him in a reasonable manner for a reasonable time. Such taking into custody or detention shall not subject the officer or merchant to any criminal or civil liability. 
(b)  Any law enforcement officer may arrest without warrant any person he has probable cause for believing has committed the crime of shoplifting. Any merchant who causes such an arrest shall not be criminally or civilly liable if he has probable cause for believing the person so arrested has committed the crime of shoplifting. 
(Code 1984 § 16-104) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 30-16-23. 
Sec. 10-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - LAW ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 10-46. - Unauthorized wearing of uniform or badge. 
(a)  Unauthorized wearing of uniform or badge consists of the wearing, without authorization by the city of a uniform or badge or both whose material, color or design, or any combination of them, is such that the wearer appears to be a member of the city police department. 
(b)  It is unlawful to commit the unauthorized wearing of uniform or badge. 
(Code 1984 § 16-17) 
State Law reference- Impersonating public officer, NMSA 1978, § 30-27-2. 
Sec. 10-47. - Unauthorized marking of motor vehicle. 
(a)  Unauthorized marking of motor vehicle consists of the marking, using, possessing or owning or requiring the marking or using, without authorization by the board, of a motor vehicle whose insignia, color or equipment, or any combination of them, is such that the motor vehicle appears to be a city police department motor vehicle. 
(b)  It is unlawful to commit the unauthorized wearing of uniform or badge or unauthorized marking of motor vehicle. 
(Code 1984 § 16-18) 
Sec. 10-48. - Obstructing an officer. 
(a)  Obstructing an officer consists of: 
(1)  Knowingly obstructing, resisting or opposing any officer of this state or any other duly authorized person serving or attempting to serve or execute any process or any rule or order of any of the courts of this state or any other judicial writ of process; 
(2)  Resisting, obstructing or abusing any judge, magistrate, or peace officer in the lawful discharge of his duties. 
(b)  It is unlawful to resist or obstruct an officer. 
(Code 1984 § 16-31; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 30-22-1. 
Sec. 10-49. - Eluding or attempting to elude an officer. 
(a)  Eluding or attempting to elude a police officer consists of: 
(1)  Intentionally fleeing, attempting to evade or evading an officer of this state when the person committing the act of fleeing, attempting to evade or evasion has knowledge that the officer is attempting to apprehend or arrest him or; 
(2)  Willfully refusing to bring a vehicle to a stop when given a visual or audible signal to stop, whether by hand, voice, emergency light, flashing light, siren or other signal, by a uniformed officer in an appropriately marked police vehicle. 
(b)  It is unlawful to elude or attempt to elude an officer. 
(Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 10-50. - Resisting arrest. 
    It is unlawful to resist a lawful arrest. 
(Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 10-51. - Concealing identity. 
(a)  Concealing identity consists of concealing one's true name or identity, or disguising oneself with intent to obstruct the due execution of the law or with intent to intimidate, hinder or interrupt any public officer or any other person in a legal performance of his duty or the exercise of his rights under the laws of the United States, the State of New Mexico or the City of Roswell. 
(b)  It is unlawful to commit concealing identity. 
(Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 10-52. - Failure to appear or answer citation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to appear or answer any notice or citation issued by the city police. 
(Code 1984 § 16-32) 
State Law reference- Citations authorized, NMSA 1978, § 35-15-3. 
Secs. 10-53-10-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - MINORS 

Sec. 10-56. - Curfew for minors. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any juvenile under the age of 18 years to be in or upon any of the streets of the city, to loiter, idle, wander, stroll or play in or upon the public streets, highways, roads, alleys, parks, playgrounds or other public grounds, public places and public buildings, places of amusement or entertainment, vacant lots or other unsupervised places at any time between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m., excepting therefrom Fridays and Saturdays, and on Fridays and Saturdays at any time between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 5:00 a.m. unless accompanied by a parent or guardian or other adult person having the care and custody of such minor or juvenile or where the minor is upon an emergency-errand or legitimate business directed by his parent, guardian or other adult person having the care and custody of such juvenile. Each violation of the provisions of this subsection shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian or other adult person having the care and custody of any juvenile, male or female, to knowingly permit such juvenile to be in violation of subsection (a). The provisions of this subsection shall not apply when such minor is accompanied by his parent, guardian or other adult person having the care and custody of such juvenile or where such juvenile is upon an emergency errand or legitimate business directed by his or her parent, guardian or other adult person having the care and custody of such juvenile. Each violation of the provisions of this subsection shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1984 § 16-33) 
Sec. 10-57. - Truancy. 
(a)  No person under the age of 18 years shall be upon or about public streets, public places of amusement and entertainment within the city during the hours when said person is required to be in attendance at either a public or private school as required by state law. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a person to encourage or assist a student not to attend or return to school unless said absence is excused by a school official or such absence is excused under one of the exceptions found in the ordinance or such excuse is recognized by law. 
(c)  Parent(s) or legal guardian of school children who violate this section will be given a warning on the first violation, a $50.00 fine on the second violation, and a $100.00 fine on each subsequent violation. 
(d)  Students who violate this mandatory school attendance will be identified and the proper school officials and the parent or legal guardian of the student shall be notified and summoned to court for a hearing on the matter. 
(e)  This section is in no way intended to replace the "New Mexico Compulsory School Attendance Law" found at NMSA 1978, Art. 12, §§ 22-12-1 through 22-12-7. 
(f)  This section is in no way intended to replace any truancy supervision by the school districts, private schools or any other school recognized by law. 
(Code 1984 § 16-33.1; Ord. No. 1235, 11-1994) 
Sec. 10-58. - Sale, display, possession by minors of aerosol spray paint in cans; penalties. 
(a)  No person shall sell glue or aerosol spray paint in cans to any person under 18 years of age. A New Mexico driver's license or, identification card issued to a member of the armed forces, or an identity card issued pursuant to NMSA 1978, § 60-10-17, shall be prima facie proof of age. 
(1)  Any person that shall intentionally buy, procure, or provide spray paint to a minor for the purpose of defacing property will be charged with the offense of contributing to the delinquency of a minor as stated in NMSA 1978, § 30-6-3. 
(b)  Any person who owns, manages or operates a place of business in which aerosol spray paint in cans is sold, shall conspicuously post a notice by heading or title of this section in such place of business in letters at least three-eighths-inch high. To read, "SALE, DISPLAY, POSSESSION BY MINOR OF AEROSOL SPRAY PAINT IN CANS IS PROHIBITED BY LAW, City of Roswell Municipal Ordinance: 1244." 
(c)  No person under 18 years of age shall have in his possession any can of aerosol spray paint while in any public place, except under the supervision of a parent or other parentally approved adult supervisor whether such person is or is not in any automobile, vehicle or other conveyance. 
(d)  No person shall intentionally smell, sniff or inhale the fumes or vapors from a glue, aerosol spray product or other chemical substance for the purpose of causing a condition of or inducing symptoms of intoxication, elation, euphoria, dizziness, excitement, irrational behavior, exhilaration, stupefaction or dulling of the senses, or for the purpose of in any manner changing, distorting or disturbing the audio, visual, or mental processes. 
(e)  No person shall intentionally possess a glue, aerosol spray product or other chemical substance for any purpose set forth in subsection (d) of this section. 
(f)  As used in this section, "glue" means what is commonly referred to as plastic or model airplane cement and includes any cement containing hexane, benzene, toluene, xylene, carbon tetrachloride, chloroform, ethylene dichloride, acetone, cyclohexanone, methyl ethyl ketone, methyl isobutyl ketone, amyul acetate, butyl acetate, ethyl acetate, tricresol phosphate, butyl alcohol, ethyl alcohol, isopropyl alcohol or methyl cellosolve acetate. 
(g)  Third and subsequent convictions of subsections (d) and (e) will be processed through magistrate court. 
(Code 1984 § 16-36; Ord. No. 1244, 9-1993; Ord. No. 00-7, § 3, 9-2000) 
Sec. 10-59. - Educational neglect of a child. 
(a)  As used in this section: 
    Child means a person who is less than 13 years of age who is subject to compulsory school attendance under state law. 
    Educational neglect occurs when a parent, guardian or custodian of a child, either knowingly or through neglect, causes, allows or fails to prevent the absence of that child from school without an authorized excuse for more than ten days during any school year. 
    Authorized excuse means an allowable excuse pursuant to the compulsory school attendance law or the rules of the local school board or governing body of a charter school or private school. 
(b)  Records maintained by a local public school, charter school or private school in the ordinary course of business which list dates of unexcused absences of a child shall be prima facie evidence of unexcused absences. 
(c)  A parent, guardian or custodian of a child who commits or allows educational neglect to occur shall be guilty of a petty misdemeanor. 
(d)  A citation shall be served in lieu of arrest when a parent, guardian or custodian is charged with educational neglect under this section directing the appearance of that person before the municipal court. 
(e)  Each set of ten unexcused absences shall be considered a separate count of educational neglect. 
(Ord. No. 16-11 , § 1, 6-9-2016) 
Sec. 10-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - PROPERTY 

Sec. 10-61. - Trespass-Generally. 
(a)  Criminal trespass consists of unlawfully entering or remaining upon the lands of another knowing that such consent to enter or remain is denied or withdrawn by the owner or occupant thereof. 
(b)  Criminal trespass also consists of unlawfully entering or remaining upon lands owned, operated or controlled by the state or any of its political subdivisions knowing that consent to enter or remain is denied or withdrawn by the custodian thereof. 
(c)  Criminal trespass also consists of any person who enters upon the lands of another without prior permission and injures, damages or destroys any part of the realty or its improvements, including buildings, structures, trees, shrubs or other natural features. 
(d)  It is unlawful to commit criminal trespass. 
(Code 1984 § 16-4; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 3-14-1. 
Sec. 10-62. - Same-Injury to realty, etc. 
    It is unlawful to commit injury to realty, which consists of: 
(1)  Any person who enters and remains on the lands of another after having been requested to leave. 
(2)  Any person who enters upon the lands of another when such lands are posted against trespass at every roadway or apparent way of access. 
(3)  Any person who drives a vehicle upon the lands of another except through a roadway or other apparent way of access, when such lands are fenced in any manner. 
(4)  In the event any person enters upon the lands of another without prior permission and injures, damages or destroys any part of the realty or its improvements, including buildings, structures, trees, shrubs or other natural features, he shall be liable to the owner, lessee or person in lawful possession for damages in an amount equal to double the amount of the appraised value of the damage of the property injured or destroyed. 
(Code 1984 § 16-5) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 30-14-1.1; posting of land, NMSA 1978, § 3-14-6. 
Sec. 10-63. - Criminal damage to property. 
(a)  Criminal damage to property consists of intentionally damaging any real or personal property of another and doing less than $1,000.00 damage without the consent of the owner of the property. 
(b)  It is unlawful to commit criminal damage to property. 
(Code 1984 § 16-6) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 30-15-1. 
Sec. 10-64. - Damaging trees, shrubs, etc. 
    No person shall pluck, purloin, injure or destroy any tree, flowers, shrub or plant growing in the public parks or in or around any private yard, garden or enclosure belonging to any private citizen within the city, unless permission to do so shall first have been obtained from a person in authority or the owner. 
(Code 1984 § 16-7) 
Sec. 10-65. - Destruction, misuse, etc., of public property. 
    No person shall misuse, take, disfigure or destroy any public property. 
(Code 1984 § 16-8) 
State Law reference- Malicious mischief, NMSA 1978, § 30-15-1. 
Sec. 10-66. - Posting requirements. 
(a)  The owner, lessee or person lawfully in possession of real property in New Mexico, except property owned by the state or federal government, desiring to prevent trespass or entry onto the real property shall post notices parallel to and along the exterior boundaries of the property to be posted, at each roadway or other way of access in conspicuous places, and if the property is not fenced, such notices shall be posted every 500 feet along the exterior boundaries of such land. 
(b)  The notices posted shall prohibit all persons from trespassing or entering upon the property, without permission of the owner, lessee, person in lawful possession or his agent. The notices shall: 
(1)  Be printed legibly in English; 
(2)  Be at least 144 square inches in size; 
(3)  Contain the name and address of the person under whose authority the property is posted or the name and address of the person who is authorized to grant permission to enter the property; 
(4)  Be placed at each roadway or apparent way of access onto the property, in addition to the posting of the boundaries; and 
(5)  Where applicable, state any specific prohibition that the posting is directed against, such as "no trespassing," "no digging" or any other specific prohibition. 
(c)  Any person who posts public lands contrary to state or federal law or regulation is guilty of a petty misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 16-19 , § 1, 11-10-2016) 
Secs. 10-67-10-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - PUBLIC MORALS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-71. - Indecent exposure-Generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit indecent exposure, consisting of knowingly and indecently exposing the private parts or sexual organs of a person to the public view. 
(Code 1984 § 16-26) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 30-9-14. 
Sec. 10-72. - Same-Person in establishments serving food or alcoholic beverages. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, owner, proprietor, manager, keeper or the agent, employee or servant of any such owner, proprietor, manager or keeper of any establishment serving food or alcoholic beverages, or both, including, but not limited to, a lounge, tavern, retail liquor dispenser, hotel, motel or other place open to the public within the city, for pay or otherwise, knowingly to show, cause to be shown, exhibited or otherwise exposed to public view, in and upon such premises, one or both breasts in the person of any entertainer, performer, employee, agent or other individual. 
(Code 1984 § 16-27) 
State Law reference- Indecent waitering, NMSA 1978, § 30-9-14.2. 
Secs. 10-73-10-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - OBSCENITY 

Sec. 10-76. - Definitions. 
(a)  In this article: 
(1)  Obscene means material or a performance that: 
a.  The average person, applying contemporary community standards, would find that taken as a whole appeals to the prurient interest in sex; 
b.  Depicts or describes: 
1.  Patently offensive representations or descriptions of ultimate sexual acts, normal or perverted, actual or simulated, including sexual intercourse, sodomy, and sexual bestiality; or 
2.  Patently offensive representations or descriptions of masturbation, excretory functions, sadism, masochism, lewd exhibition of the genitals, the male or female genitals in a state of sexual stimulation or arousal, covered male genitals in a discernibly turgid state or a device designed and marketed as useful primarily for stimulation of the human genital organs; and 
c.  Taken as a whole, lacks serious literary, artistic, political, or scientific value. 
(2)  Material means anything tangible that is capable of being used or adapted to arouse interest, whether through the medium of reading, observation, sound, or in any other manner, but does not include an actual three-dimensional obscene device. 
(3)  Performance means a play, motion picture, dance, or other exhibition performed before an audience. 
(4)  Promote means to manufacture, issue, sell, give, provide, lease, rent, deliver, transfer, transmit, publish, distribute, circulate, disseminate, present, exhibit, or advertise, or to offer or agree to do the same. Nothing herein shall be construed so as to restrict or prohibit the use of material or devices by adults in the privacy of personal residence not for monetary gain or valuable consideration. 
(5)  Wholesale promote means to manufacture, issue, sell, provide, mail, deliver, transfer, transmit, publish, distribute, circulate, disseminate, or to offer or agree to do the same for the purpose of resale. 
(6)  Obscene device means a device including a dildo, or artificial vagina designed or marketed as useful primarily for the stimulation of human genital organs. 
(b)  If any of the depictions or descriptions of sexual conduct described in this section are declared by a court of competent jurisdiction to be unlawfully included herein, this declaration shall not invalidate this section as to other patently offensive sexual conduct included herein. 
(Code 1984 § 19-16) 
Sec. 10-77. - Obscene display or distribution. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if he: 
(1)  Intentionally or knowingly displays or distributes an obscene photograph, drawing, or similar visual representation or other obscene material; 
(2)  Knowing its content and character, he wholesale promotes or possess with intent to wholesale promote any obscene material or obscene device; 
(3)  Knowing its content and character, he: 
a.  Promotes or possesses with intent to promote any obscene material or obscene device; or 
b.  Produces, presents, or directs an obscene performance or participates in a portion thereof that is obscene or that contributes to its obscenity. 
(b)  It is unlawful to violate this section. 
(Code 1984 § 19-17) 
Sec. 10-78. - Nonapplication to law enforcement authority. 
    This article does not apply to a person who possesses or distributes obscene material or obscene devices or participates in conduct otherwise proscribed by this section when the possession, participation, or conduct occurs in the course of law enforcement activities. 
(Code 1984 § 19-18) 
Sec. 10-79. - Destruction of materials seized. 
    Any material or device, as previously defined in this article, seized pursuant to this article is contraband and shall be destroyed following the appropriate order of court. 
(Code 1984 § 19-20) 
Sec. 10-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PROSTITUTION 

Sec. 10-81. - Prostitution-Generally. 
(a)  Prostitution consists of knowingly engaging in or offering to engage in sexual penetration for hire. 
(b)  As used in this section "sexual penetration" means sexual intercourse, cunnilingus, fellatio, anal intercourse, or the causing of penetration to any extent and with any object, of the genital, anal or oral opening of another, whether or not there is any emission. 
(c)  It is unlawful to commit prostitution. 
(Code 1984 § 16-66) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 30-9-2. 
Sec. 10-82. - Bawdy houses, houses of ill fame, etc. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep a bawdy house, disorderly house, house of ill fame, resorted to for the purpose of prostitution or lewdness or assignation house. 
(b)  A house of prostitution is a public nuisance per se. 
(Code 1984 § 16-68) 
Sec. 10-83. - Patronizing prostitutes. 
(a)  Patronizing prostitutes consists of: 
(1)  Entering or remaining in a house of prostitution, or any other place where prostitution is practiced, encouraged or allowed, with intent to engage in sexual penetration with a prostitute; or 
(2)  Knowingly hiring or offering to hire a prostitute to engage in sexual penetration with the actor or another. 
(b)  As used in this section, "sexual penetration" means sexual intercourse, cunnilingus, fellatio, anal intercourse or the causing of penetration, to any extent and with any object, of the genital, anal or oral opening of another whether or not there is any emission. 
(c)  It is unlawful to patronize prostitutes. 
(Code 1984 § 16-69; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, NMSA 1978, § 30-9-3.
