    The city engineer and the city attorney shall act in an advisory capacity to such commission. 
(Code 1984 § 24-17; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions generally, § 2-96 et seq. 
Sec. 19-13. - Officers and meetings. 
    It shall carry out the purposes for which such commission is created, not inconsistent with the legislative acts of the state and ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1984 § 24-18; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
State Law reference- Planning commission officers, rules, etc., NMSA 1978, § 3-19-3. 
Sec. 19-14. - Powers generally. 
    The city planning and zoning commission shall exercise all authority granted to commissions of this character by NMSA 1978, § 3-19-1 et seq. In addition, it shall exercise all powers and perform all duties set out in NMSA 1978, § 3-21-1 et seq., as well as those set out in this article, together with laws amendatory thereof and supplemental thereto. 
(Code 1984 § 24-19; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 19-15. - Duties generally. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the city planning and zoning commission to formulate general plans and designs to promote the welfare, beauty and comfort of the city, to improve and develop means of transportation, ornamentation, drainage, sewerage and all other means of municipal improvement. The commission shall, from time to time, submit to the governing body, reports, maps and plans for such purposes. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the commission to keep itself informed as to the progress of the city planning in this and other communities, and to make studies and recommendations for the improvement of the sanitation, recreation and general welfare of the public, and to improve traffic transportation and the general convenience of the public. 
(Code 1984 § 24-20) 
State Law reference- Functions of planning commission generally, NMSA 1978, § 3-19-4 et seq. 
Sec. 19-16. - When city to act on plans, proposals or ordinances. 
    When any plan, proposal or ordinance shall have been referred by the governing body to the city planning and zoning commission, the city shall not take action thereon until the expiration of the time allowed for the report and recommendation of the commission. 
(Code 1984 § 24-21) 
Sec. 19-17. - Submission of reports and recommendations-Generally. 
(a)  Whenever any plan, proposal or ordinance relating to matters coming within the duties or jurisdiction of the city planning and zoning commission shall have been referred to the commission for consultation or advice, the commission shall return the same to the governing body with its report and recommendation thereon in writing within 30 days after the same shall have been referred to it, unless the governing body shall, in referring same, direct that a longer or shorter period shall be allowed for such report, but upon the request or recommendation of the commission, the time for the making of such report and recommendation may be extended within the discretion of the governing body. 
(b)  The commission shall submit to the governing body plans, reports and recommendations concerning the development of facilities for public recreation, the development and improvement of public parks, boulevards, highways and other grounds, the improvement of rivers, and the extension and opening of streets and highways. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the commission to formulate and submit to the governing body reports and plans for dividing the city into districts of such numbers, shape, area and form as may be deemed best, and submit reports and plans regulating or restricting the erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration, repair or use of buildings, structures or lands within such districts. 
(d)  It shall be the duty of the commission to submit to the governing body reports, plans and recommendations to regulate and restrict the height, number of stories and size of buildings and other structures, percentage of lots that may be occupied, the size of yards, courts and other open spaces, the density of population and the location and use of buildings, structures and lands for trade, industry, residences or other purposes. 
(Code 1984 § 24-22) 
Sec. 19-18. - Same-Annual report. 
    On or before the fifteenth day of March of each year, the planning and zoning commission shall make a written report to the mayor and governing body of the work of the commission during the preceding year. Such report shall summarize all recommendations made by the commission to the governing body during the year, and all references by the governing body to the commission of matters for investigation, report or advice, together with the action of the governing body, if any, taken thereon. Such report shall contain the general program of improvements for the city, as shall be recommended by the commission, and may contain estimates of cost and recommendations as to the means of defraying the same. 
(Code 1984 § 24-23) 
Sec. 19-19. - Dwellings unfit for human habitation. 
(a)  Dwellings which are unfit for human habitation include, but are not limited to, those which are unfit due to dilapidation; defects increasing risk of fire, accidents, or other calamities, lack of ventilation, light, sanitary facilities, uncleanliness, dilapidation, or structural defects, or which are otherwise unsafe or unsanitary or dangerous or detrimental to the health, safety, or welfare, of occupants of the dwelling, occupants of neighboring dwellings, or other residents of the municipality, or which have a blighting influence on neighboring properties, or which are in violation of any health, fire, building, or zoning regulations or any other laws or regulations relating to the use of land and the use and occupancy of buildings and improvements, shall be subject to this ordinance. 
(b)  By adopting this ordinance, the City of Roswell is authorized by statute to require or cause the repair, closing, demolition, or removal of a dwelling unfit for human habitation as provided for in this section. 
(1)  Dwelling means any building or structure or part thereof intended to be used for human occupancy and includes any appurtenances usually enjoyed in the dwelling. 
(c)  The city attorney is appointed to exercise the powers prescribed by this article in coordination with the planning and zoning committee. 
(1)  The city attorney is also authorized to exercise powers as may be necessary or convenient to carry out and effectuate the purposes and provisions of the Urban Development Law, including the following powers, in addition to others granted in the Urban Development Law: 
a.  To have City code enforcement officers investigate the dwelling conditions in the municipality in order to determine which dwellings are unfit for human habitation; 
b.  To administer oaths and affirmations, examine witnesses, and receive evidence; 
c.  To have city code enforcement officers enter upon such premises for the purpose of making examinations, provided that the entries shall be made in a manner as to cause the least possible inconvenience to those involved and to obtain an order for this purpose form a court of competent jurisdiction in the event entry is denied or resisted; 
d.  To appoint and fix the duties of any officers, agents, and employees as it deems necessary to carry out the purposes of the ordinance; and 
e.  To delegate any of his functions and powers under the ordinance to officers, agents, and employees as he may designate. 
(d)  Whenever it appears to the city attorney that a dwelling is unfit for human habitation, the city attorney shall, if a preliminary investigation discloses a basis for the charges, call a special meeting of the planning and zoning committee to inform the planning and zoning committee of his findings and allow discussion among the planning and zoning members. Should the city attorney and the planning and zoning committee members agree to proceed with the case, the city attorney shall issue and cause to be served on the owner, every mortgagee of record, and all parties in interest in that dwelling, a complaint stating the charges and including the following: 
(1)  Notice that a hearing will be held before the city attorney, at a place named in the complaint, not less than ten or more than 30 days after the serving of the complaint; 
(2)  Notice that the owner, mortgagee, and parties in interest shall be given the right to file an answer to the complaint and to appear in person or otherwise and give testimony at the place and time fixed in the complaint; and 
(3)  Notice that the rules of evidence prevailing in courts of law or equity shall not be controlling in hearings before the city attorney or his designee. 
    The city attorney shall notify planning and zoning committee members of the hearing date and make available to them all evidence relating to the case. 
(e)  If, after notice and hearing, the city attorney and the planning and zoning committee members determine that the dwelling under consideration is unfit for human habitation, he shall state in writing his findings of fact in support of that determination and shall cause to be served upon the owner an order, in writing, that advises the owner of his rights under this section, and that: 
(1)  If the repair, alteration or improvement of the dwelling can be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the value of the dwelling, the city attorney and the planning and zoning committee shall fix a certain percentage of the cost as being reasonable for that purpose and require the owner, within the time fixed in the order, to repair, alter, or improve the dwelling to render it fit for human habitation, or to vacate and close the dwelling as a human habitation, the latter only after following statutory procedures regarding tenants' rights; or 
(2)  If the repair, alteration, or improvement of the dwelling cannot be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the value of the dwelling, the city attorney and the planning and zoning committee shall fix a certain percentage of the cost as being reasonable for the purpose and require the owner, within the time specified in the order, to remove or demolish the dwelling; 
(3)  If the owner fails to comply with an order to repair, alter, improve, or vacate and close the dwellings, the city attorney and the planning and zoning committee may cause the dwelling to be repaired, altered, or improved, or to be vacated and closed; 
(4)  If the owner fails to comply with and order to remove or demolish the dwelling, the city attorney and the planning and zoning committee may cause the dwelling to be removed and demolished; and 
(5)  The amount of the cost of repairs, alterations, or improvements, or the vacating and closing, or the removal and demolition shall be assessed as a lien against the real property upon which the cost was incurred; and 
a.  If the dwelling is removed or demolished by order of the city attorney and the planning and zoning committee, the city shall sell the materials of the dwelling and credit the proceeds of the sale against the cost of the removal or demolition; and 
b.  Any balance remaining shall be deposited in the district court by the city attorney and shall be secured in the manner as may be directed by the court, and shall be disbursed by the court to the person(s) found to be entitled to the balance by final order or decree of the court. 
(f)  Complaints or orders issued by the city attorney shall be served upon persons either personally or by registered mail. If the whereabouts or the persons are unknown and cannot be ascertained by the city attorney in the exercise of reasonable diligence, and the city attorney makes an affidavit to that effect, then the serving of the complaint or order upon the persons may be made by publishing the complaint or order once each week for two consecutive weeks in a newspaper printed and published in the municipality. A copy of the complaint or order shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the premises affected by the complaint or order. A copy of the complaint or order shall also be filed with the clerk of the county in which the dwelling is located. Filing of the complaint or order shall have the same force and effect as other lis pendens notices provided by law. 
(g)  Any person affected by an order issued by the city attorney may file an appeal pursuant to the provisions of NMSA 1978, § 12-8A-1. 
(h)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to abrogate or impair the powers of the courts or of a department of a municipality to enforce any provisions of its ordinances or regulations, or to prevent or punish violations thereof. The powers conferred by this ordinance shall be in addition and supplemental to the powers conferred by any other law. 
(Ord. No. 1313, 08-1999) 
Secs. 19-20-19-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - NUMBERING OF BUILDINGS 

Sec. 19-26. - Compliance. 
    All buildings fronting on the streets or avenues in the city shall be numbered in conformity with the provisions of this article. It shall be unlawful for any owner, occupant or agent of any building in the city to refuse, fail or neglect to number such building within the time specified in section 19-29 or number or attempt to number such building otherwise than in conformity with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1984 § 24-36: Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 19-27. - Scheme. 
    Odd numbers shall be given to all buildings on the north and east sides of the streets and avenues and even numbers to those on the south and west side. Stairways shall be marked with half numbers. On streets and avenues running eastwardly and westwardly in the city, numbering shall commence at No. 100 at Main Street and increase in each direction at the rate of 100 numbers for each block or space of ground between two streets or avenues; to distinguish such numbers, such streets shall be designated counting from Main Street east and west, as East First Street and West First Street. On streets and avenues running northwardly and southwardly in the city numbering shall commence at No. 100 at First Street, and increase in each direction at the rate of 100 numbers for each block or space of ground between two streets or avenues, and to distinguish such numbers, the streets aforesaid shall be designated counting from said First Street north and south, as North Main Street and South Main Street. 
(Code 1984 § 24-37) 
Sec. 19-28. - Allocation of numbers. 
    In designating the numbers of all buildings in conformity with this article, one number shall be allowed for each lot or space of ground 25 feet in width in that portion of the city constituting the business portion, and in that portion of the city described as constituting the residence portion, one number shall be allowed for each lot or space of ground 50 feet in width. For the purposes of this article and the numbering of buildings the business portion shall be that part of Main Street included between Rio Hondo and North Spring River, all that part of Richardson Avenue and Virginia Avenue included between Alameda Avenue and Fifth, and all that portion of Alameda Avenue, Walnut, First, Second, Third, Fourth, and Fifth Streets included between Richardson Avenue and Virginia Avenue. The building inspector, on application of the owner or agent of any building, shall designate the proper number thereof. 
(Code 1984 § 24-38) 
Sec. 19-29. - Display of numbers. 
(a)  Every owner or occupant of any building shall place on such building, in a conspicuous place next to the street on which it fronts, the proper number thereof in figures not less than four inches in height. If the lot or portion of a lot occupied by a single dwelling house is of a sufficient width to require more than one number, it shall be sufficient to place on such house the number of the lot on which the main front entrance thereof is situated. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any owner or occupant of a building to fail to display the correct number of such building in compliance with the provisions of this article. Upon a first conviction the person shall be warned; upon a second conviction the person may receive a fine of no more than $50.00. 
(c)  The sanctions imposed under subsection (b) will go into effect July 1, 1999. 
(Code 1984 § 24-39; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999; Ord. No. 00-7, § 3, 9-2000) 
State Law reference- Authority to require numbering, NMSA 1978, § 3-49-1. 
Chapter 20 - RAILROADS 

Sec. 20-1. - Unauthorized persons riding, etc., on cars. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, without proper authority, to get upon freight or other railroad cars in the city for the purpose of braking or riding on such cars or for any other purpose, except as a passenger coming to or going from the station in the city. 
(Code 1984 § 26-1) 
Sec. 20-2. - Planks between tracks crossing streets. 
    All railroad companies running and operating their railroad tracks across the streets of the city shall build, construct and maintain a plank roadway between their several tracks, and between the rails of their several tracks, across the entire width of the streets between sidewalks. The plank roadways shall be securely built and constructed level with the railroad tracks, in such manner that the railroad tracks will not make any obstruction to vehicles crossing them. 
(Code 1984 § 26-2) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to regulate railroad crossings, NMSA 1978, § 3-18-21(A)(3); highway crossings, NMSA 1978, § 63-3-5 et seq.; municipal authority to regulate railroads, NMSA 1978, § 3-18-21; railroads generally, NMSA 1978, § 63-1-1 et seq. 
Chapter 21 - SOLID WASTES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 21-1. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to establish minimum standards and requirements for the collection and disposal of solid wastes generated within the city in a manner consistent with guideline criteria promulgated by the environmental improvement agency, an instrumentality of the state. The provisions contained in this chapter are hereby declared to be regulatory and not for the purpose of revenue; and further, such regulations are necessary to protect and secure the public health, safety and general welfare, and are intended by way of implementation where they are not in conflict with pertinent laws and regulations of the state or any agency thereof in such case made and provided. In the event any requirement or provision herein shall be in conflict with or contrary to any such provision or regulation of state law, such state law or regulation shall prevail. 
(Code 1984 § 27-1) 
Sec. 21-2. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Collection means the process of collecting or gathering solid waste for transportation to a point of disposal or sanitary landfill. 
    Disposal facility means the sanitary landfill or site for the disposal of solid wastes. 
    Incineration means the process of reducing combustible solid wastes to inert residue, in a device or chamber designed for complete combustion. 
    Motor vehicle is any vehicle which is designed to be self-propelled and travel along the ground and shall include, but not be limited to, automobiles, buses, motorbikes, motorcycles, motorscooters, trucks, tractors, go-carts, golf carts, recreational vehicles and motor homes. 
    Person means any person owning, operating or controlling any house, residence, shop, commercial establishment, hotel, restaurant, market, apartment, condominium or tenement house or any other place of business within the city, to include tenants, lessees or occupants. 
    Premises means business houses, apartment houses, offices, theaters, hotels, residences, commercial establishments of any character, settlements, hospitals, schools, vacant lots and all other places within the corporate limits where solid waste accumulates. 
    Private property shall mean any real property within the city which is privately owned and which is not public property, as defined in this section. 
    Public property shall mean any street or highway which shall include the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained for the purposes of vehicular travel and shall also mean other publicly owned property or facility. 
    Recycling means the segregation of reusable materials preparatory to industrial processing of such materials, whereby such material is converted into a new product so that the original product is no longer identifiable. 
    Sanitation officer means the department head of the sanitation department of the city. 
    Scavenging means the removal of solid waste from a disposal facility. 
    Solid waste means garbage, rejected or waste food, offal, swill, carrion, ashes, dirt, slop, waste water, trash, rubbish, cast-off items, parts of autos, clothing, mattresses, tires, paper, cartons, salvage or unwholesome materials of any kind or description; except sewage, but including commercial, industrial, institutional and recreational wastes and any article or substance commonly discarded as waste or which, if discarded on the ground, will create or contribute to an unsanitary, offensive or unsightly condition. 
(Code 1984 § 27-2) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority relative to solid wastes, NMSA 1978, § 3-48-1 et seq. 
Cross reference- Litter, ch. 16, Art. II; disposal of dead animals, § 4-3; water, sewers and sewage disposal, ch. 26; utility billing and collection procedures, ch. 26, art. V. 
Sec. 21-3. - Enforcement. 
    It shall be the duty of the sanitation officer to supervise the handling and collection of all solid waste within and for the city, as well as the disposal thereof. He shall enforce such regulations as the governing body may from time to time adopt, relating to procedures, schedule of charges and frequency and times of solid waste collection, including the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1984 § 27-3) 
Sec. 21-4. - Placement on streets, etc.; transportation. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any reason for any person to sweep, place or throw solid waste or other waste materials in or upon any sidewalk, street, alley or unoccupied premises. Included in the prohibited locations for deposit of solid waste are the streets and roadways providing access to the municipal landfill in the area of the corner of Brasher Road and Eisenhower Road and the properties adjoining such streets, specifically, but not limited to, Brasher Road from the city limits to the landfill and Eisenhower Road from the city limits to the landfill. 
(b)  No solid waste shall be transported upon the city's sidewalks, streets, or alleys except in such manner that the waste is confined and bound to the transporting vehicle so as to prevent its blowing, falling, or otherwise being accidentally separated from the vehicle during transit. 
(Code 1984 § 27-4) 
Secs. 21-5-21-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MUNICIPAL COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL SERVICE 

Sec. 21-11. - City's exclusive right to collect solid wastes. 
    The city and its duly authorized agents, servants or employees reserve the exclusive right to collect or gather solid waste within the city. It shall be unlawful for any person to collect or gather solid waste within the city; provided, however, that waste materials not defined by this chapter, such as sawdust, manure, fertilizers, manufacturing operations, trees, tree trimmings no longer than four feet and other large, heavy, bulky materials, building construction materials or other scrap solid waste from construction, remodeling, demolition or excavation shall be hauled by the contractor or builder if the work is done by contract; otherwise, by the owner or occupant or his duly authorized agent. Such materials on streets, lots or adjacent areas shall be deposited at the solid waste disposal area under the direction of the sanitation officer or his duly authorized agent. 
(Code 1984 § 27-16) 
Sec. 21-12. - City's duty to provide for disposal of solid wastes. 
    The city shall be responsible to provide and maintain suitable equipment to collect and dispose of solid waste generated within the city and adequate areas for the disposal thereof. 
(Code 1984 § 27-17) 
Sec. 21-13. - Manner of disposal generally. 
(a)  Solid waste shall be disposed of in the manner prescribed by the sanitation officer. 
(b)  No material as may be prohibited by the state environmental improvement agency will be accepted for disposal in the landfill. 
(Code 1984 § 27-18) 
Sec. 21-14. - Use and maintenance of disposal area. 
    Solid waste collected by the city or other authorized persons shall be deposited at such point or areas as may be designated by the governing body as the solid waste disposal area. The solid waste disposal area shall be maintained in such a manner as not to become a public nuisance and, in any case, shall be maintained in accordance with the duly adopted regulations of the environmental improvement agency of the state. 
(Code 1984 § 27-19) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to compel the taking of refuse to designated places, NMSA 1978, § 3-48-2. 
Sec. 21-15. - Scavenging, removal or grazing at disposal area. 
    All solid waste deposited in and upon the solid waste disposal area shall be the property of the city. It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Scavenge; 
(2)  Separate, collect, recycle or carry off any solid waste in the solid waste disposal area without the special permission of the sanitation officer; 
(3)  Graze animals upon the area designated as the solid waste disposal area. 
(Code 1984 § 27-20) 
State Law reference- Authority to operate refuse disposal area, NMSA 1978, § 3-48-2. 
Sec. 21-16. - Containers generally. 
(a)  Every person owning, leasing or occupying premises within the city shall provide one or more of the following types of waste containers: 
(1)  Manually transported containers. 
(2)  Mechanically transported containers. 
(3)  Containers for automated pickup. 
(4)  Incinerators. 
    Such containers shall be provided in sufficient number to contain and accommodate any and all solid waste accumulated by such person between collection periods. 
(b)  Containers provided shall conform to the following specifications: 
(1)  Mechanically transported containers. 
a.  Mechanically transported containers shall be in accordance with specifications to be approved by the city manager, and no mechanically transported container shall be placed to serve any premises, either in the street or in the alley, without prior approval of the city manager. The sanitation officer is authorized to designate the locations of any such containers, considering, among other things, accessibility and convenience to collection crews and to the customer, hazardous conditions such as electric wires, if any, and obstacles or means of approach. 
b.  Each owner, tenant, occupant, lessee or person in charge of or controlling premises shall be held responsible for maintaining the area surrounding mechanically transported containers and racks in clean and sanitary condition, free of weeds, tall grass, brush, briars, tree sprouts and solid waste scattered by reason of overturned dumpsters and shall keep the lids on the dumpsters closed at all times to prevent the scattering of solid waste, which shall be cause for the issuance of a citation to appear in municipal court. 
(2)  Container for automated pickup. 
a.  In areas served by automated collection equipment the city shall furnish a sufficient number of containers to serve the area. At the city's sole discretion containers may be placed to serve several surrounding residences or other users. When the city determines it is necessary, it may supply individual roll-out containers for a single user. Location of the container shall be determined by the city. 
b.  All persons using automated collection containers shall deposit solid wastes for collection only in the containers. Material left outside a container will not be collected except by arranged special collections. Persons using any of the automated collection containers are encouraged to place waste material in plastic bags prior to depositing it in the containers. No loose garbage or similar wet material or loose material likely to be blown about shall be placed in the automated collection containers unless it is first bagged in a plastic bag of at least one mil thickness. 
c.  Persons using individual automated collection containers and having curbside pickup shall place them at the designated pickup location in advance of scheduled collection times but shall not allow the containers to remain at the curb for longer than 24 hours. 
(3)  Incinerators. Incinerators located on the premises involved may be approved for the burning of solid waste, such approval to be evidenced in writing by the appropriate governmental authority. 
(c)  All solid waste receptacles shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition by the owner or person using the receptacle, and such receptacles shall be located only in such places as shall be readily accessible for removing and emptying such receptacles, but shall not be placed in such a place or position as may constitute a nuisance or obstruction to vehicular or pedestrian traffic. In cases of dispute or complaint incidental to the location of any such receptacle placed for the removal of contents, the sanitation officer shall designate a place, and such designation shall be final. 
(Code 1984 § 27-21; Ord. No. 1273, 10-1995; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999; Ord. No. 01-2, 10-2001) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to acquire and regulate receptacles, NMSA 1978, § 3-48-2. 
Sec. 21-17. - Disturbing contents of containers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb or scatter the solid waste or contents of the solid waste receptacles required by section 21-16. 
(Code 1984 § 27-22; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 21-18. - Preparation of bulky solid waste for collection. 
(a)  Subject to the other ordinances, solid waste such as boxes, cartons, cases, barrels and other shipping containers, discarded furniture, trees, tree and shrubbery trimmings of size or bulk too great for the metal containers herein required may, at the option of the person in charge of the premises where such solid refuse accumulates, be prepared for collection as follows: 
(1)  Such bulky solid waste shall be compressed as compactly as possible and broken or cut into shortened lengths, as the need may be, and securely tied in bundles not exceeding four feet in length and 50 pounds in weight. 
(2)  Boxes, cartons, cases, etc., shall be nested with the smaller boxes inside of the larger boxes. The maximum overall dimensions of the nested solid waste shall not exceed four feet nor 50 pounds in weight. 
(3)  In the preparation of solid waste under either subsection (1) or (2), no refuse such as papers, light packing materials or other similar or easily scattered materials shall be included in the bundling and nesting, and such bundled or nested solid waste may be placed adjacent to the metal containers for collection. 
(4)  Such other method as may be approved by the sanitation officer may be adopted for the disposal and handling of salvage, appliances, tires, mattresses, auto parts and other household items. If any such method approved by the sanitation officer shall require time of the sanitation department equipment and employees for such collection in excess of the time required for collection under subsection (1), (2) or (3) hereof, an additional charge over and above the normal monthly charge for collection and removal of solid waste from such premises will be made. Such additional charge will be computed upon the average hourly cost of equipment and for the additional hours per month required. The sanitation officer shall not in any case approve a plan for preparation for removal or holding for removal of any solid waste, bulky or otherwise, that permits the depositing of solid waste in any street, alley or public way in any manner which will permit its being scattered. 
(5)  Grass clippings and weeds shall be put in plastic bags and/or cardboard boxes for pick-up with the weight of the containers not to exceed 35 pounds each. 
(b)  To be accepted for disposal tires larger than passenger tires must be cut into two pieces by cutting at center tread or by removing both beads by cutting sidewalls. 
(Code 1984 § 27-23; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999; Ord. No. 01-2, 10-2001) 
Sec. 21-19. - Frequency of collections. 
    Solid wastes from all users of the city's solid waste collection and disposal service shall be collected twice each week except as otherwise provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1984 § 27-24) 
Sec. 21-20. - Fees. 
(a)  Every person owning or controlling real property within the city shall pay the solid waste collection and disposal fees established and provided for by this chapter, whether or not the solid waste collection and disposal service is used by the person owning or controlling real property within the city. 
(b)  Monthly services for solid waste collection and disposal from dwellings and residential premises shall be assessed against the person in whose name the water meter for the premises is registered of record. Minimum charges for such residential service shall be as provided herein. Such charge is premised on twice a week pickup of the shared use of an automated collection container or the use of an individual automated collection container. Charges for such residential service for a calendar month shall be, plus applicable gross receipts tax: 
Collection Disposal (1) Single family residence $7.05 $4.70 (2) Duplexes, per unit 7.05 4.70 (3) Accessory dwelling 7.05 4.70

(c)  Monthly services not described in subsection (b) shall be considered commercial property. Charges shall be assessed against the person in whose name the water meter for the premises is registered of record. Charges for such services for a calendar month shall be determined as follows, plus applicable gross receipts tax:

(d)  The sanitation department shall not accept special or hazardous waste and may at any time refuse to collect, or refuse to accept for disposal, waste the department determines would be detrimental to operation of the collection system or landfill. Waste deemed unacceptable by the department shall not be presented for disposal or disposed of at the city's landfill unless such determination is amended prior to presentment or disposal. 
(e)  (1)  The fee for disposal of solid waste at the disposal area, for residential user only, on loads consisting of 300 pounds or less shall be a flat rate of $2.80 per load, plus applicable gross receipts tax. 
(2)  The fee for disposal of solid waste at the disposal area, including, but not limited to, compacted loads, roll-offs, yard waste, etc., for all commercial loads and residential loads in excess of 300 pounds shall be $30.00 per ton, plus applicable gross receipt taxes. 
(3)  The fee for disposal of heavy solid waste, defined as large tree trunks, asphalt roofing shingles, etc. that is not considered clean fill, at the disposal area shall be $14.30 per ton, plus applicable gross receipts tax. 
(4)  The fee for disposal of clean fill solid waste, defined as concrete, brick, rock, soil, asphalt, rebar, glass, etc. that meets clean fill standards as approved by the State of New Mexico Environment Department, at the disposal area shall be $10.75 per ton plus applicable gross receipt taxes. 
(5)  The fee for the disposal of tires for residential users and for all commercial loads, at the disposal area shall be $2.25 per standard passenger tire, $4.50 per standard truck tire, $0.10 (ten cents) per pound for large tires, defined as larger than standard truck tires; and bulk tires shall be $200.00 per ton with a limited amount of rims (1 per 100) allowed; or $400.00 on a bulk load of tires contaminated with other trash, plus applicable gross receipt tax on all. 
(6)  The fee for disposal of E-waste, defined as electronic waste such as but not limited to computer monitors, computer towers, printers, scanners, copy machines, batteries, universal surge protectors, telephones, two way radios, cell phones, radios, VCR and DVD equipment, etc., at the disposal area shall be $35.00 per ton plus $1.00 per unit, plus applicable gross receipts tax. 
(7)  The fee for disposal of refrigerant units, defined as any cooling or heating unit containing refrigerant that requires evacuation by state standards before disposal such as but not limited to refrigerators, freezers, heat pumps, AC units, drinking water coolers, etc., at the disposal area shall be $35.00 per ton plus $10.00 per evacuation, plus applicable gross receipts tax. 
(8)  Tickets will contain the customer name, address, date, receipt number, weigh master signature/identification number and materials description, and will be invoiced monthly. 
(9)  The above landfill disposal fees shall be automatically adjusted at the beginning of each fiscal year, beginning July 1, 2012, to the nearest 25 cent point of the Consumer Price Index for Urban Wage Earners and Clerical Workers (CPI-W) information obtained from the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the U.S. Department of Labor. 
(f)  For the purpose of convenience, the billing and collecting of the charges levied for service under subsections (b) and (c) of this section shall be done by the city water department, and all such charges shall be payable at the office of the city water department in the same manner as are other utility services billed and collected by the city water department. 
(g)  The city may provide and maintain roll-off containers to the public at a rate of not less than $160.00 per pull plus tonnage as weighed at the Roswell Landfill. Bins shall be place for service in a manner and location acceptable to the city. Length of time for use of a city owned roll-off container is 30 calendar days. Additional days will be charged at a rate of $5.00 per day up to 30 additional days. Continued usage of the containers over 60 days requires approval from the sanitation officer or agent. Businesses or individuals must give the solid waste department 24 hours notice when the roll-off containers need to be pulled and the content of the roll-off shall not exceed 40,000 pounds. Damage to the container will be the responsibility of the business or individual using the container and will be billed accordingly. 
(Code 1984 § 27-25; Ord. No. 1215, § 1, 7-1991; Ord. No. 1237, § 1, 4-1993; Ord. No. 1273, 10-1995; Ord. No. 01-2, 10-2001; Ord. No. 02-11, 11-2002; Ord. No. 11-01, 4-2011; Ord. No. 11-02, 4-2011) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to impose solid waste or refuse collection fees, NMSA 1978, § 3-48-3(C); procedures for collection of fees, NMSA 1978, §§ 3-48-3-3-48-7. 
Cross reference- Utility billing and collection procedures, ch. 26, art. V. 
Chapter 22 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Obstructions generally. 
(a)  No persons shall gather in crowds on any sidewalk or any street, avenue or alley so as to obstruct or hinder travel or so as to encumber the same. 
(b)  The city reserves the right to remove from a street, sidewalk or right-of-way any object that obstructs the free flow of pedestrian or vehicular traffic thereon. This includes but is not limited to obstructions impairing the line of sight, trees, signs, walls, shrubs and vehicles. 
(Code 1984 § 28-1; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999; Ord. No. 00-7, § 3, 9-2000) 
Sec. 22-2. - Selling or delivering goods on sidewalks. 
(a)  No person shall offer for sale, sell or deliver goods, wares or merchandise of any kind or character upon any public sidewalk except as permitted by the city and shall not do so in such a manner as to temporarily or permanently obstruct the free passage of pedestrians any portion of the sidewalk. 
(b)  No wholesale or retail dealer in merchandise or services of any kind or character, or his agent or employee, shall service, deliver or cause, allow or permit the delivery of goods. wares or merchandise of any kind or character to any vehicle or the occupant thereof which, at the time of such delivery, is occupying any portion of a public sidewalk or in any manner obstructing the free passage of pedestrians over any portion of the sidewalk. 
(c)  No owner or operator of any vehicle of any kind or character shall cause, allow or permit such vehicle to remain stationary or parked upon any public sidewalk or to cause, allow or permit such vehicle to be stopped or parked in such a manner as to obstruct the free passage of pedestrians over any portion of the sidewalk. 
(Code 1984 § 28-2) 
Cross reference- Sale of goods on city property generally, § 10-99. 
Sec. 22-3. - Use of street centers for making surveys, etc. 
    No person other than professional engineers and licensed land surveyors licensed in accordance with the laws of the state shall have the privilege of using street centers for the purpose of making surveys or for any other purpose. 
(Code 1984 § 28-3) 
Secs. 22-4-22-10. - Reserved. 
State Law reference- Municipal authority relative to streets, sidewalks and public grounds, NMSA 1978, § 3-49-1 et seq. 
Cross reference- Moving buildings, § 6-41 et seq.; sale of goods on city property, § 10-99; drainage and flood control, ch. 11, littering on streets, sidewalks, etc., §§ 16-17, 16-19, 16-20; numbering of buildings, ch. 19, art. III; repair of railroad street crossing, § 20-2; traffic, ch. 24; regulations on transporting radioactive materials within city, § 24-5. 
ARTICLE II. - CONSTRUCTION AND EXCAVATION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-11. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    City engineer means the city engineer and his delegates. 
    Public property means any city-owned real property, as well as improvements therein, thereon or thereunder, including but not limited to easements granted to or reserved by the city, streets, alleys, public rights-of-way, parking lots, buildings, structures, water and sewer systems and property previously dedicated to the city within one year after the work is performed, by filing a plat thereof with the county clerk. 
    Work means construction, alteration, addition, removal, repair, replacement, excavation, ditching, tunneling, paving, grading and tamping in, upon, over, under, across or through public property. 
(Code 1984 § 28-16) 
Sec. 22-12. - General applicability of article. 
    The requirements of this article shall apply in all cases of work performed on public property, unless otherwise expressly limited or exempted by this article. 
(Code 1984 § 28-17) 
Sec. 22-13. - Applicability to franchised utility companies. 
    Utility companies which have been enfranchised by ordinance of the city shall be exempt from the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1984 § 28-18) 
Sec. 22-14. - Applicability of article to government agencies. 
    Agencies of the federal or state governments and agencies or departments of the city shall be exempt from the bonding requirements of this article. Federal and state agencies or departments shall submit an application for a permit for work to be preformed for each proposed work site. 
(Code 1984 § 28-19) 
Sec. 22-15. - Applicability to sidewalks. 
    Sidewalks on public property shall be governed by the provisions of this section. Sidewalks on private property shall be subject to the building code as adopted by the city. Construction of sidewalk shall require issuance of building permit from the city. 
    Maintenance, repairs, and reconstruction of all sidewalks shall be the responsibility of owner(s) of property which abuts such sidewalks. Property owners(s) shall be responsible for replacement of any removed sidewalk within 30 days of removal, with the exception of removal of sidewalk done by a governmental agency. The city shall not be responsible for such maintenance or replacement of sidewalk, unless the maintenance, removal or replacement is caused by the City of Roswell. 
(Code 1984 § 28-20; Ord. No. 13-03 , § 1, 1-10-2013) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to provide for street construction, NMSA 1978, § 3-49-1. 
Cross reference- Building code adopted, § 6-11 et seq. 
Sec. 22-16. - General authority of city engineer. 
    All streets, alleys, public rights-of-way and city real property shall be under the general control and supervision of the city engineer for engineering purposes, subject to the direction of the director of public works, the city manager, the mayor, and the governing body of the city, and only in the manner authorized by the city engineer. The city engineer is hereby empowered to provide engineering services and to charge a reasonable fee therefor, to be paid to the city, for all work performed on public property. 
(Code 1984 § 28-21) 
Sec. 22-17. - Rules and regulations. 
    The city engineer shall promulgate rules and regulations for work performed on city property. It is unlawful to negligently or willfully fail or refuse to strictly comply with such rules and regulations and is hereby found and declared to be a hazard to the public health, welfare and safety of the members of this community, and a public nuisance. The city attorney, upon the express authorization of the governing body, may pursue any remedy at law or in equity which the governing body deems necessary to abate, prevent or correct such nuisance. 
(Code 1984 § 28-22; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 22-18. - Responsibility for compliance. 
    The person submitting an application for a permit to perform work on public property may subcontract any or all of the proposed work, but shall nevertheless be considered to be the person responsible for ensuring that the work is performed in strict compliance with the standards and guidelines of the city engineer as a minimum level of performance. Although work may be delegated, the application for a permit shall bind the applicant and the qualified party, jointly and severally, to a nondelegable duty to the city to perform work in strict compliance with the rules and regulations of the city engineer. The applicant and the qualified party to whom the state construction industries commission has issued a contractor's license shall be the persons responsible for ensuring strict compliance with the minimum standards and guidelines of the city engineer, notwithstanding the supervisory authority of the city engineer. 
(Code 1984 § 28-23) 
Secs. 22-19-22-25. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 22-26. - Required. 
    No person shall perform work on public property until the building inspector has issued a permit to such person for such work. 
(Code 1984 § 28-36) 
Sec. 22-27. - Application. 
    The building inspector shall not issue a permit required by this article until the applicant has filed with the building inspector a formal written application, in a form approved by the city manager. The application shall be signed by the applicant and shall contain a statement by which the applicant agrees to hold and save the city harmless and to indemnify the city, for any and all liability incurred by or resulting from the proposed work to be performed on public property. The application form shall indicate any license number and the qualifying party to whom a license has been issued, as well as the specific kinds of work which are permitted, of the contractor's license issued by the state construction industries commission. The application form may contain such other information as the city engineer or the city manager deem necessary. 
(Code 1984 § 28-37; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 22-28. - Fee. 
    The building inspector shall not issue a permit required by this article until the applicant has filed a fee with the building inspector for the permit. Such fee shall be as established by rule or regulation of the city engineer. The purpose of this fee shall be to offset costs of enforcement of this article and shall not be for purposes of revenue. 
(Code 1984 § 28-38; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 22-29. - Bonds. 
(a)  The building inspector shall not issue a permit required by this article until the applicant has filed with the building inspector a good and sufficient surety bond, payable to the city as obligee, in an amount equal to 100% percent of the estimated value of the material to be furnished and of the labor to be performed on the proposed work, as well as a bond in an amount equal to 100% percent of the estimated value of the proposed work as a performance bond to ensure completion of the proposed work within a reasonable time. The materials and labor bond described above shall be and remain in effect for a period of one year from the date of completion of the work, or for a period of one year from the cessation of work, whether completed or not, and shall be in all respects acceptable to the city. A cash bond of equal amount may be substituted for the surety bond. 
(b)  The city may execute upon the performance bond notwithstanding any other remedy at law or in equity which the city may have, in the event that the proposed work is not completed within a reasonable period of time, in a workmanlike manner in compliance with the terms of the period and the requirements of the city engineer. The city may execute upon the labor and materials bond in the event that a defect in labor or materials is discovered during the time the bond is in effect. 
(Code 1984 § 28-39; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 22-30. - Denial. 
    In the event that the city engineer deems the issuance of a permit to be not in the best interests of the city, due to a potential hazard to the health, safety or welfare of the community, the city engineer may refuse to issue a permit for work on public property. Such refusal may be appealed to the governing body by filing a notice of appeal with the city clerk, not more than ten working days after receiving a written notice from the city engineer, setting forth the grounds for refusal. The governing body shall thereafter hear and determine whether a permit should be issued at its next regular meeting. The city engineer shall provide a written notice setting forth the grounds for refusing to issue a permit within two working days after receiving an application for permit. 
(Code 1984 § 28-40) 
Secs. 22-31-22-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ADOPTION OF MANUAL ON UNIFORM TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES 

Sec. 22-36. - Manual adopted by reference. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article, the latest edition of the Manual On Uniform Traffic Control Devices, including revisions, as promulgated by the Federal Highway Administration, United States Department of Transportation, is adopted by reference pursuant to NMSA 1978, § 3-17-6(A). The adoption of said manual shall make it an administrative code of the City of Roswell, New Mexico. 
(Code 1984 § 28-45; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 22-37. - Code available for inspection. 
    A copy of the latest edition of the Manual On Uniform Traffic Control Devices, including revisions, shall be kept in the office of the city engineer and shall be available for inspection during the normal and regular business hours of the city engineer. 
(Code 1984 § 28-46; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 22-38. - Copies of code; purchase. 
    A copy of the latest edition of the Manual On Uniform Traffic Control Devices, including revisions, may be purchased upon request and with payment of a reasonable charge. 
(Code 1984 § 28-47; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999; Ord. No. 00-7, § 3, 9-2000) 
Sec. 22-39. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PERMIT PARKING[1] 

Footnotes:
