(2)  The term penalty assessment misdemeanor does not include any violation which has caused or contributed to the cause of an accident resulting in injury or death to any person. 
(3)  When an alleged violator of a penalty assessment misdemeanor elects to accept a notice to appear in lieu of a notice of penalty assessment, no fine imposed upon later conviction shall exceed the penalty assessment established for the particular penalty assessment misdemeanor and no probation imposed upon a suspended or deferred sentence shall exceed 90 days. 
(4)  The penalty assessment for speeding in violation of Section 12-6-1.2 (4) or the Uniform Traffic Ordinance is twice the penalty assessment established in section 24-2(a) of this article for the equivalent mile per hour over the speed limit. 
(5)  In addition to the penalty assessment established for each penalty assessment misdemeanor pursuant to this section, there shall be assessed the following fees for each penalty assessment misdemeanor: a $20.00 corrections fee; a $6.00 court automation fee; and a $3.00 judicial education fee. 
(b)  Penalty assessment misdemeanors; option; effect. 
(1)  Unless a warning notice is given, at the time of making an arrest for any penalty assessment misdemeanor, the arresting officer shall offer the alleged violator the option of accepting a penalty assessment. The violator's signature on the penalty assessment notice constitutes an acknowledgment of guilt of the offense stated in the notice, and payment of the prescribed penalty assessment is a complete satisfaction of the violation. 
(2)  Payment of any penalty assessment must be made by mail to the Municipal Court, Traffic Violations Bureau, City of Roswell, New Mexico within 30 days from the date of arrest. Payments of penalty assessments are timely if postmarked within the time limits set from the date of the arrest. The traffic violations bureau shall issue a receipt when a penalty assessment is paid by currency, but checks tendered by the violator upon which payment is received are sufficient receipt. 
(3)  No record of any penalty assessment payment is admissible as evidence in any court in any civil action. 
(c)  Failure to pay penalty assessment. 
(1)  If a penalty assessment is not paid within 30 days from date of arrest, the violator shall be prosecuted for the violation charged on the penalty assessment notice in a manner as if a penalty assessment notice had not been issued. Upon conviction in such prosecution, the court shall impose penalties as provided by the New Mexico Uniform Traffic Ordinance (Section 12-12-1.1) or other law relating to motor vehicles for the particular offense charged, and the schedule of penalty assessments shall not apply. 
(2)  In addition to the prosecution provided for in subsection 4(a), it is a misdemeanor for any person who has elected to pay a penalty assessment to fail to do so within 30 days from the date of arrest. 
(3)  The office of the municipal court shall notify the Motor Vehicle Division of the State of New Mexico when a person fails to pay a penalty assessment within the required period of time. The motor vehicle division shall report the notice upon the driver's record and shall not renew the person's license to drive until the municipal court notifies the motor vehicle division that the penalty assessment, or its equivalent, as well as any penalties imposed are properly disposed of. 
(Code 1984 § 29-2; Ord. No. 1261, 4-1995; Ord. No. 1263, 5-1995; Ord. No. 1268, 7-1995; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999; Ord. No. 06-05, 08-2006; Ord. No. 16-21 , § 1, 3-9-2017; Ord. No. 18-10 , § 1, 12-13-2018) 
Sec. 24-3. - Additional penalty assessment fees for violations. 
    Any person violating any ordinance relating to the operation of a motor vehicle for which a penalty assessment schedule has been established, and who chooses to pay the penalty assessment, shall pay, in addition to the penalty assessment, a penalty assessment fee of $10.00. All penalty assessment fees, collected above and beyond the penalty assessment, shall be deposited in a special fund in the municipal treasury and shall be used solely for municipal jailer training, the construction planning, construction, operation and maintenance of a municipal jail, for paying the cost of housing municipal prisoners in other detention facilities in the state or complying with match or contribution requirements for the receipt of federal funds relating to jails. 
(Code 1984 § 29-3) 
Sec. 24-4. - Special court costs for violations. 
    Any person convicted of violating any ordinance relating to the operation of a motor vehicle shall pay a $20.00 corrections fee to the municipal judge who shall collect such fees as court costs. All correction fees collected pursuant to this section shall be deposited in a special fund in the municipal treasury and shall be used solely for municipal jailer training, the construction planning, construction, operation and maintenance of a municipal jail, for paying the cost of housing municipal prisoners in a county jail or complying with match or contribution requirements for the receipt of federal funds relating to jails. 
(Code 1984 § 29-4) 
State Law reference- Ordinance required, NMSA 1978, § 35-14-11. 
Sec. 24-5. - Regulations on transportation of radioactive materials through city. 
    Transportation of radioactive materials in quantities exceeding the "Type A quantity," established in 10 CFR 71-4 (1986), is hereby prohibited except as provided for herein: 
(1)  Transportation of quantities of radioactive materials exceeding the Type A quantities, but specifically excepted from transportation requirements in 10 CFR 71 (1986), is permitted in accord with such exceptions. 
(2)  Transportation of quantities of radioactive materials exceeding the Type A quantities shall be, so far as possible, restricted to the Roswell Relief Route-Bypass. The use of other streets shall be permitted only if delivery is to be made to an in-city site away from those streets, or material is to be removed from such a site. In the event there is an emergency on the bypass which renders it impassable, the fire chief or his designee will designate Main Street or Second Street as the alternate route. 
(3)  No transportation of quantities of radioactive materials exceeding the Type A quantities shall occur without first having reported the intent to transport the materials, together with the times and route to the city police chief or his designee. The reporting shall occur not later than two hours in advance of the proposed transportation of radioactive materials. 
(4)  As used herein, transportation refers to movement upon the public streets of the city and does not encompass movement within a structure or upon private lands. 
(Code 1984 § 29-5; Ord. No. 1309, 6-1998) 
Sec. 24-6. - Penalty amounts. 
    In the most recent version of the New Mexico Uniform Traffic Ordinance, as adopted by the city in section 24-1 of the City Code and amended by the various provisions of section 24-2 of the City Code, maximum penalty amounts that have heretofore been fixed at $300.00 are hereby amended to provide a maximum penalty amount of $500.00. Maximum penalty amounts fixed at other amounts shall remain unchanged. 
(Code 1984 § 29-6; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 24-7. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 11-04, adopted Nov. 2011, repealed former § 24-7. 
Sec. 24-8. - Operation of trucks and other commercial vehicles on certain streets. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of NMSA 1978, § 66-7-415, the residential streets in residential districts are determined to be in primarily residential areas and operation of trucks or similar commercial vehicles in excess of 26,000 pounds (GVW) is prohibited. 
Exceptions: Delivery vehicles, moving vans making deliveries to specific addresses, vehicles providing public type services to the public, i.e. local public conveyances, sanitation, telephone, cable, gas, electric, etc., and recreational vehicles. 
(1)  The portions of Berrendo Road and Mescalero Road between Main Street and Atkinson Avenue are determined to be in primarily residential areas. 
(2)  The portion of Poe Street from the intersection of Poe Street and Southeast Main Street to the intersection of Poe Street and Sunset Avenue is determined to be in a primarily residential area. 
(3)  Operation of trucks or similar commercial vehicles in excess of tow tons' load capacity is prohibited on Main Street (U.S. 70-285) between the intersections of North Main Street (U.S. 70-285) and College Avenue and South Main Street (U.S. 285) and McGaffey Street. 
(4)  The portion of East Country Club, from North Main Street to North Atkinson Avenue is determined to be a primarily residential area. 
(Code 1984 § 29-8; Ord. No. 1232, 3-1993; Ord. No. 1260, 4-1995; Ord. No. 1312, 8-1998; Ord. No. 1315, 1-1999; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999; Ord. No. 01-08, 12-2001) 
Sec. 24-9. - Authority of police service aides. 
    Police service aides are authorized to write citations for non-moving traffic violations. 
(Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 24-10. - Text-based communication prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall operate a motor vehicle while using any electronic wireless communications device to write, send or read a text-based or email communication except: 
(1)  To report illegal activity; 
(2)  To summons medical or other emergency help; 
(3)  To prevent injury to a person or property; 
(4)  While the motor vehicle is lawfully parked; 
(5)  In the operation of an authorized emergency vehicle; 
(6)  To relay information between a transit or for-hire operator and that operator's dispatcher when the device is permanently affixed to the vehicle. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, a person is not writing, reading or sending a text-based communication if the person reads, selects or enters a telephone number or name in a device for the purpose of making or receiving a telephone call. 
(c)  All terms in this section will be interpreted in compliance with the Uniform Traffic Code. 
(d)  The penalty for violation of this section will be $50.00, plus any applicable court costs which may be assessed. 
(Ord. No. 09-05, 08-2009) 
DIVISION 2. - RECREATIONAL OR UTILITY OFF-HIGHWAY VEHICLES 

Sec. 24-11. - Definitions. 
    As used in this division, the following definitions shall apply: 
    Off-highway motor vehicle means a motor vehicle designed by the manufacturer for operation exclusively off the highway or road and includes: 
(1)  Recreational or utility off-highway vehicle , which means a motor vehicle designed for travel on four or more non-highway tires, for recreational use by one or more persons, and having: 
(a)  A steering wheel for steering control; 
(b)  Non-straddle seating; 
(c)  Maximum speed capability greater than 35 miles per hour; 
(d)  Gross vehicle weight rating no greater than 1,750 pounds; 
(e)  Less than 80 inches in overall width, exclusive of accessories; 
(f)  Engine displacement of less than 1,000 cubic centimeters; and 
(g)  Identification by means of a 17-character vehicle identification number; or 
(Ord. No. 17-15 , § 1, 1-11-2018) 
Sec. 24-12. - Operation on streets or highways-Prohibited areas. 
(a)  A person shall not operate a recreational or utility off-highway motor vehicle on any: 
(1)  Limited access highway at any time; 
(2)  Paved street or highway except as provided in subsection (b) or (c) of this section; 
(3)  Walking trails; or 
(4)  City parks. 
(b)  Recreational or utility off-highway motor vehicles may cross streets or highways, except limited access highways or freeways, if the crossings are made after coming to a complete stop prior to entering the roadway. Recreational or utility off-highway motor vehicles shall yield the right of way to oncoming traffic and shall begin a crossing only when it can be executed safely and then cross in the most direct manner as close to a perpendicular angle as possible. 
(c)  A recreational or utility off-highway vehicle may be operated on a paved street owned and controlled by the city if: 
(1)  The vehicle has one or more headlights and one or more taillights that comply with the Off-Highway Motor Vehicle Act, NMSA 1978, §§ 66-3-1001-66-3-1021; 
(2)  The vehicle has brakes, mirrors, and mufflers; 
(3)  The operator has a valid driver's licenses or permits as required under the Motor Vehicle Code and off-highway motor vehicle safety permits as required under the Off-Highway Motor Vehicle Act; 
(4)  The operator is insured in compliance with the provisions of the Mandatory Financial Responsibility Act, NMSA 1978, §§ 66-5-201-66-5-248; 
(5)  A person shall not operate a recreational or utility off-highway motor vehicle or ride upon an off- highway motor vehicle without wearing eye protection that complies with the Off-Highway Motor Vehicle Act; and 
(6)  If the operator is under 18 years of age, the operator must be wearing a safety helmet that complies with the Off-Highway Motor Vehicle Act. 
(Ord. No. 17-15 , § 1, 1-11-2018) 
Sec. 24-13. - Speed limit. 
    The speed limit for recreational off-highway vehicles operated within the city shall be 45 miles per hour or the posted speed limit, whichever is less. A recreational off-highway vehicle traveling on a paved street shall travel at a speed that complies with the Off-Highway Motor Vehicle Act. 
(Ord. No. 17-15 , § 1, 1-11-2018) 
Sec. 24-14. - Passengers. 
    A person operating a recreational or utility off-highway vehicle shall ride only upon the permanent and regular seat attached thereto. The operator shall not carry any other person. No other additional person shall ride on a recreational or utility off-highway vehicle unless the vehicle is designed to carry more than one person, in which event a passenger may ride upon the permanent and regular seat, or upon another seat firmly attached, in compliance with manufacturer specifications, to the recreational or utility off-highway vehicle at the rear of the operator. 
(Ord. No. 17-15 , § 1, 1-11-2018) 
Sec. 24-15. - Obedience to traffic laws required. 
    Any person operating a recreational or utility off-highway motor vehicle shall obey all traffic laws, rules and regulations and shall be subject to the provisions of NMSA 1978, Ch. 66, Arts. 1-8. 
(Ord. No. 17-15 , § 1, 1-11-2018) 
ARTICLE II. - PARADES 

Sec. 24-16. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the term "parade" shall mean any parade, march or procession upon any street. 
(Code 1984 § 29-16) 
Sec. 24-17. - Exemptions. 
    This article shall not apply to: 
(1)  Funeral processions; 
(2)  Going to and from school classes or participating in educational activities, providing such conduct is under the immediate direction and supervision of the proper school authorities; 
(3)  A governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions. 
(Code 1984 § 29-17) 
Sec. 24-18. - Permit required. 
    No person shall engage in, participate, aid, form or start any parade without a parade permit issued by the chief of police. 
(Code 1984 § 29-18) 
Sec. 24-19. - Permit applications. 
(a)  A person desiring a parade permit shall file an application with the chief of police on forms provided by such officer. Such application shall be filed not less than seven days nor more than 60 days before the date on which it is proposed to conduct the parade. 
(b)  The application for a parade permit shall set forth the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct such parade; 
(2)  If the parade is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of, or by an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization, and of the authorized and responsible heads of such organization; 
(3)  The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the parade chairman and who will be responsible for its conduct; 
(4)  The date when the parade is to be conducted; 
(5)  The route to be traveled, the starting point and the termination point; 
(6)  The approximate number of persons who, and animals and vehicles which, will constitute such parade; the type of animals, and description of the vehicles; 
(7)  The hours when such parade will start and terminate; 
(8)  A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only a portion of the width of the streets proposed to be traversed; 
(9)  The location by streets of any assembly areas for such parade; 
(10)  The time at which units of the parade will begin to assemble at any such assembly area or areas; 
(11)  The interval of space to be maintained between units of such parade; 
(12)  If the parade is designed to be held by, and on behalf of or for, any person other than the applicant, the applicant for such permit shall file with the chief of police a communication in writing from the person proposing to hold the parade, authorizing the applicant to apply for the permit on his behalf; 
(13)  Any additional information which the chief of police shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether a permit should issue; 
(14)  The chief of police, where good cause is shown therefor, shall have the authority to consider any application hereunder which is filed less than seven days before the date such parade is proposed to be conducted. 
(Code 1984 § 29-19; Ord. No. 00-7, § 3, 9-2000) 
Sec. 24-20. - Standards for permit issuance. 
    The chief of police shall issue a parade permit when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained, he finds that: 
(1)  The conduct of the parade will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route; 
(2)  The conduct of the parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of this municipality to properly police the line of movement and the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police protection to this municipality; 
(3)  The conduct of such parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of ambulances as to prevent normal ambulance service to portions of this city other than that to be occupied by the proposed line of march and areas contiguous thereto; 
(4)  The concentration of persons, animals and vehicles at assembly points of the parade will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection of or ambulance service to areas contiguous to such assembly areas; 
(5)  The conduct of such parade will not interfere with the movement of firefighting equipment en route to a fire; 
(6)  The conduct of the parade is not reasonably likely to cause injury to persons or property, to provoke disorderly conduct or create a disturbance; 
(7)  The parade is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays en route; 
(8)  The parade is not to be held for the sole purpose of advertising any product, cause, goods or events and is not designed to be held purely for private profit. 
(Code 1984 § 29-20; Ord. No. 00-7, § 3, 9-2000) 
Sec. 24-21. - Notice of permit denial. 
    If the chief of police disapproves the application, he shall mail to the applicant a notice of his disapproval within three days of receipt of the application. 
(Code 1984 § 29-21; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 24-22. - Alternative permit. 
    The chief of police, in denying an application for a parade permit, shall be empowered to authorize the conduct of the parade on a date, at a time, or over a route different from that named by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept an alternate permit shall, within five days after notice of the action of the chief of police, file a written notice of acceptance with the chief of police. An alternate parade permit shall conform to the requirements of and shall have the effect of a parade permit under this article. 
(Code 1984 § 29-22) 
Sec. 24-23. - Contents of permit. 
    Each parade permit shall state the following information: 
(1)  Starting time: 
(2)  Minimum speed; 
(3)  Maximum speed; 
(4)  Maximum interval of space to be maintained between the units of the parade; 
(5)  The portions of the streets to be traversed that may be occupied by the parade; 
(6)  The maximum length of the parade in miles or fractions thereof; 
(7)  Such other information as the chief of police shall find necessary to the enforcement of this article. 
(Code 1984 § 29-23) 
Sec. 24-24. - Carrying permit. 
    The parade chairman or other person heading or leading such activity shall carry the parade permit upon his person during the conduct of the parade. 
(Code 1984 § 29-24) 
Sec. 24-25. - Revocation of permit. 
    The chief of police shall have the authority, after a hearing affording due process, revoke a parade permit issued hereunder upon application of the standards for issuance as set forth in this article. 
(Code 1984 § 29-25) 
Sec. 24-26. - Compliance with laws and regulations. 
    A person holding a parade permit shall comply with all permit directions and conditions and with all applicable laws and ordinances. 
(Code 1984 § 29-26) 
Chapter 25 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 25-1. - Certificate of public convenience and necessity required. 
(a)  On and after the effective date of this section, all persons, corporations, or organizations engaging in the transportation of persons and property by motor vehicle for hire upon the streets of the City of Roswell shall possess a certificate of public convenience and necessity issued by the State of New Mexico pursuant to the Motor Carrier Act, NMSA 1978, § 65-2-80 et seq. The exemptions in said subparagraph are hereby expressly declared inapplicable within the city and activities subject to obtaining a certificate of convenience and necessity but for such exemptions shall be required to have a certificate. 
(b)  No business subject to this section and subject to the business registration requirements of the city shall be allowed to register without presenting its certificate or satisfactory evidence that it possesses the required certificate of public convenience and necessity. 
(Code 1984 § 30.5-1) 
Secs. 25-2-25-5. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - AMBULANCE SERVICES 
DIVISION 1. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 25-6. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to set forth the requirements for the inspection, licensure and operation of ambulance services and ambulance vehicles within the City of Roswell. These rules and regulations will assist in assuring quality emergency pre-hospital care and medical transportation services to all citizens of the city. 
(Code 1984 § 30.5-21) 
Sec. 25-7. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this article, unless the content otherwise requires: 
    Ambulance means any vehicle especially constructed or modified and equipped, intended to be used, and maintained or operated for the transportation, upon the streets of this city, of individuals who are sick, injured, or otherwise incapacitated or helpless. 
    Ambulance driver means any person authorized to drive an ambulance, as provided in this article. 
    Ambulance service means the furnishing, operating, conducting, maintaining, advertising, or otherwise engaging in or professing to be engaged in the transportation of patients by ambulance. Taken in context, it also means the person so engaged or professing to be so engaged. 
    Ambulance service license shall mean those licenses issued by the city following satisfactory fulfillment of the conditions found in this article. 
    Ambulance vehicle permit means the authorization issued by the city with respect to an ambulance used or to be used to provide ambulance service in this city. 
    Applicant means that person who is an initial applicant or an applicant for renewal of an ambulance service license, ambulance vehicle permit, or an emergency medical technician license. 
    Council means the city council of Roswell. 
    City means the City of Roswell, New Mexico. 
    City manager means the city manager of the City of Roswell. 
    Emergency medical technician means an individual who holds a valid emergency medical technician license issued by the New Mexico Emergency Medical Services Bureau of the New Mexico Department of Health. It is understood that the bureau may certify more than one category of emergency medical technician, and that each such category is included within the definition of emergency medical technician for this article. 
    Operate means to pick up and transport injured, sick or disabled within the city, regardless of the basing address of the emergency medical vehicles service or ambulance service. 
    Patient means any individual who is sick, injured or otherwise incapacitated or helpless. 
    Medical director means a physician who is licensed by the State of New Mexico and who is actively involved in the pre-hospital aspects of emergency medical care. 
(Code 1984 § 30.5-22; Ord. 1290, 6-1997) 
Sec. 25-8. - Requirements for licensure of emergency medical vehicles. 
(a)  After May 1, 1984, no person shall provide ambulance service in this city unless that person holds a valid ambulance service license to do so issued by the city, except as provided in subsections (1) through (3). Licenses, permits and renewals thereof issued under this section shall require the payment of fees in amounts not to exceed $100.00. 
(1)  The exceptional emergency use of a privately owned vehicle, not ordinarily used in the formal act of transporting patients, shall not be subject to licensure requirements. 
(2)  A vehicle rendering services as an ambulance in case of a major catastrophe or emergency when ambulances are insufficient to render services required, shall not be subject to licensure requirements. 
(3)  Ambulances based outside the State of New Mexico when transporting a patient to or through the city shall not be subject to the licensure requirements. 
(4)  Vehicles used or designed for the scheduled transportation of convalescent patients or handicapped individuals not requiring prone or recumbent transportation, or persons who would not be expected to require any skilled care or treatment while in the vehicle, are not subject to licensure requirements. 
(b)  Every applicant for an ambulance service license and ambulance vehicle permit shall complete and submit to the city an original application for approval. The application shall contain, but not be limited to the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the owner of each ambulance. 
(2)  The name, address and telephone number of the person applying for the license, hereinafter referred to as the applicant. 
(3)  The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be in charge of the operation of the ambulance service. 
(4)  The training and experience of the applicant and of the person who will be in charge of the ambulance service. 
(5)  The trade or other name, if any, under which the applicant does business or proposes to do business. 
(6)  If the owner of an ambulance or the applicant is a corporation, the name and address of each stockholder owning ten percent or more of the outstanding stock of each such corporation and the names and addresses of each of the directors of the corporation. 
(7)  A description of each ambulance, including the make, model, year of manufacture, motor and chassis numbers, a New Mexico State License Number for the current year, New Mexico State Emergency Vehicle Permit, the length of time the ambulance has been in use, and the color scheme, insignia, name, monogram and other distinguishing characteristics used to designate the ambulance. 
(8)  The location and description of the place or places from which it is intended to operate an ambulance service. 
(9)  The area to be served by the proposed ambulance service. 
(10)  Copies of the insurance policies as are set forth in this article. 
(11)  Check or cash in the amount of $100.00. 
(c)  Obtaining or attempting to obtain an ambulance service license or ambulance vehicle permit by fraudulent means or misrepresentation will be grounds for denial, suspension or revocation of the license or permit. 
(d)  After receipt of an original application for a license to provide ambulance service, the city shall review the application and the applicant's record. The city shall issue an ambulance service license to the applicant to provide ambulance service and an ambulance vehicle permit for each ambulance used, both of which shall be valid for 12 months following the date of issue, upon a finding that the applicant's record vehicles, equipment and staff comply with the licensing requirements of this article. 
(e)  Any ambulance service license or ambulance vehicle permit, unless revoked by the city, may be renewed by filing an application as in the case of an original application. Applications for renewal shall be filed annually, but not less than 30 days before the date of expiration. 
(f)  The city may grant a conditional license to an ambulance service if such service is not in compliance at the time of initial application, pursuant to the provisions of this article. Such conditional license shall be valid for not less than 30 days nor more than 90 days. Such conditional license shall require the ambulance service to provide the ambulance administrative oversight committee with either a written plan of action to comply with the provisions of this article or evidence of compliance within 30 days of issuance. 
(g)  The city manager shall appoint an inspector who shall inspect all ambulance vehicles at the time of application for an ambulance service license and at his discretion thereafter, to determine condition of said vehicle with regard to safety, warning systems, equipment, supplies, basic sanitation, sterility of equipment in patient contact, and other related requirements as adopted by the city. 
(h)  Each ambulance operated by an ambulance service shall be issued a permit. In order to be approved for a permit the applicant shall present evidence that the vehicle has passed the city inspection within the past year and that its equipment meets or is equivalent to the minimum requirements set forth in the latest revision of Ambulance Standards Rule 252 of the New Mexico State Corporation Commission. In order to be approved for an advanced life support vehicle permit, the applicant shall present evidence that the vehicle has in addition, met any such further requirements concerning advanced life support equipment as may be established by the ambulance administrative oversight committee. 
(i)  Each ambulance shall be equipped with such lights, sirens and special markings as required by Federal Department of Transportation Specifications KKK 1822-A, as amended, and shall be in compliance with all applicable state statutes and regulations. 
(j)  All ambulances shall display clear and permanent identification on both sides, visible at all times, showing the name of the service under which they licensed. 
(k)  Each ambulance vehicle permit shall be displayed in a prominent place within the interior of the ambulance vehicle. Upon a determination by the city manager that an ambulance is in noncompliance with this article, he may have such ambulance vehicle permit removed until proper compliance is accomplished. 
(l)  No ambulance shall operate in the city unless it has the following insurance in force at the time of operation: 
(1) Vehicle liability; Combined single limit $1,000,000.00 per person. (2) General liability (professional 
liability); General aggregate $1,000,000.00 Personal and adv. injury 1,000,000.00 Each occurrence 1,000,000.00 (3) Excess liability; Each occurrence 2,000,000.00 Aggregate 2,000,000.00 (4) Property damage; Per occurrence 100,000.00  
(Code 1984 § 30.5-23; Ord. No. 1290, 6-1997) 
Sec. 25-9. - Requirements for the operation of ambulances. 
(a)  No patient shall be transported in an ambulance in this city after May 1, 1984, unless there are two or more individuals, including the driver present and authorized to operate said ambulance. All ambulance services responding to emergency calls shall be required to provide the following for the transportation of patients: 
(1)  An advanced life support ambulance occupied by at least one emergency medical technician-paramedic and one emergency medical technician-basic. 
(2)  Sufficient medical malpractice and vehicular liability insurance coverage as defined in section 25-8(l)(1) through (4). 
(3)  A medical director as defined in section 25-8 of this article. 
(4)  Ambulances which provide sufficient space and capability for the performance of cardiopulmonary resuscitation, airway maintenance, suctioning, and ceiling height sufficient to meet design criteria in Federal Department of Transportation Specifications KKK 1822-A, as amended. 
(b)  At all times there shall be at least one attendant in the patient compartment of the ambulance while transporting a patient. 
(Code 1984 § 30.5-24; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 25-10. - Suspension or revocation of license. 
(a)  The city, after written notice and opportunity for hearing to the licensee of an ambulance service, may suspend or revoke any license or permit in any case in which it finds there has been incompetent care and/or an attempt to obtain a license by fraudulent means or misrepresentation. 
(b)  In any legal action filed against a person who had been issued an ambulance service license pursuant to this article, in which it is alleged that the plaintiff's injury, illness or incapacity was exacerbated or that he was otherwise injured by licensee negligence, an act of negligence shall not be presumed based on the allegation. 
(Code 1984 § 30.5-25) 
Sec. 25-11. - Documentation system. 
    Each ambulance service shall prepare and transmit copies of uniform and standardized records, as specified, concerning the transportation and treatment of patients, in order to evaluate the performance of the emergency medical services system and medical transportation services and to plan systematically for improvements to said system. 
(Code 1984 § 30.5-26) 
Sec. 25-12. - Public convenience and necessity. 
(a)  The city reserves the exclusive right to limit the number and scope of providers of ambulance service to the number and scope necessary to provide adequate services to the city. 
(b)  Any applicant for licensure must show that the public convenience and necessity requires additional licensee. 
(c)  Second and subsequent emergency ambulance services must meet the same licensing, training, certification and equipment criteria before they will be called. 
(Code 1984 § 30.5-27; Ord. 1290, 6-1997) 
Sec. 25-13. - Safety clause. 
    The city hereby finds, determines and declares that this article is necessary for the immediate preservation of the public health and safety. 
(Code 1984 § 30.5-28) 
Secs. 25-14, 25-15. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - AMBULANCE ADMINISTRATIVE OVERSIGHT COMMITTEE 

Sec. 25-16. - Ambulance administrative oversight committee. 
    The ambulance administrative oversight committee (formerly known as ambulance advisory board) is hereby established. The committee composition will be comprised of and serve at the discretion of the respective appointing authority: 
(1)  City of Roswell Fire Department staff member (appointed by the fire chief). 
(2)  City of Roswell staff member (appointed by city manager). 
(3)  City of Roswell at-large member (appointed by mayor with concurrence of Roswell City Council). 
(4)  Chaves County staff member (appointed by the Chaves County Manager). 
(5)  A representative from Eastern New Mexico Medical Center (appointed by the CEO). 
(6)  Roswell City Council - Fire Committee member (appointed by the chair of the fire committee). 
(7)  A member of the medical community appointed by concurrence of the City of Roswell and Chaves County. This member may include a State of New Mexico board certified medical doctor, preferably an emergency room physician. 
(8)  Any ambulance company, including air ambulances, authorized to operate in Roswell and licensed by the New Mexico State Corporation Commission is an ex officio member of the ambulance administrative oversight committee. 
(Ord. No. 1290, 6-1997) 
Sec. 25-17. - Duties of the ambulance administrative oversight committee. 
    The duties and responsibilities of the ambulance administrative oversight committee shall include but are not limited to: 
(1)  Prepare additional regulations, standards and ordinance amendments as necessary for approval by the Roswell City Council. 
(2)  Provide recommendations to the mayor, Roswell City Council and city manager on such subjects relating to ambulance service they deem necessary. 
(3)  Act as a mediator of billing or billing practices and complaints. 
(4)  Investigate any areas of concern that may be assigned it by the mayor, Roswell City Council or city manager. 
(5)  In the event an ambulance service receives funds from the City of Roswell, provide oversight review over those funds. 
(6)  Convene at least once per quarter. However, this does not preclude convening more often as may be determined by the ambulance administrative oversight committee. 
(7)  Comply with the State of New Mexico Open Meetings Act. 
(8)  Elect a chairperson for the committee from the sitting committee members and establish such rules and regulations as they deem necessary for the efficient conduct of the meeting. 
(9)  Provide oversight review of this article. 
(10)  May, at the committee's discretion, obtain input from the medical community relating to issues of a medical nature. 
(Ord. No. 1290, 6-1997) 
Chapter 26 - WATER, SEWERS AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - Tapping of mains. 
    All tapping of water and sewer mains shall be done under the supervision of code enforcement, who shall collect, in advance, from the petitioning consumer, the cost for making such tap. The superintendent of the water and sewer department shall see to the tapping of all mains and the laying of all water pipes to the property line for residences and to the curblines for business property, and the superintendent of the water and sewer department shall agree upon and determine the number and size of all taps into the water and sewer mains. The city will not lay pipes except mains for water pipes to the curbline and property line where mains have been laid, such piping to be laid by the city for which the consumer shall pay the actual cost of such laying before the water is turned on. A service water pipe or tap intended to supply more than one dwelling or premises must be provided with separate stopcocks placed in meter boxes on the curbline of each premise. 
(Code 1984 § 31-1; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 26-2. - Charges for extensions. 
(a)  The charge for municipal services in making water and sewer extensions shall be the cost of making the extension, plus a $4.00 per foot assessment for park development for each foot of extension; however if a dedication of appropriate park land has been recommended by the planning and zoning commission and approved by the governing body, and consented to by the developer, then only the extension charge shall be assessed. 
(b)  Fee and charge calculations for multi-family construction shall be assessed based on the following scale: 
(1)  Ten units to 24 dwelling units       (50% of all fees) 
(2)  Twenty-five units to 49 dwelling units       (35% of all fees) 
(3)  Fifty units to 74 dwelling units       (20% of all fees) 
(4)  Seventy-five dwelling units or more       (5% of all fees) 
(c)  For purposes of this section, the term "dwelling unit" shall mean one or more rooms within a residential multi-family structure, designed for one individual or family, living within such structure independently as a single housekeeping unit. 
( Ord. No. 13-04 , § 1, 2-14-2013; Ord. No. 15-02 , § 1, 4-9-2015) 
Sec. 26-3. - Charges for service beyond city limits. 
    The charge for water and sewer services furnished to locations outside the limits of the city shall be twice the amount charged for such services within the city. When the city manager determines, however, that a water or sewer service is temporary, the city manager shall recommend reasonable charges for the particular service and such charges shall be effective upon approval by the city council. Charges for temporary service shall not be less than the amounts charged for such services within the city. This section shall in no way obligate the city to make such services available to locations beyond the city limits. 
(Code 1984 § 31-2.1; Ord. No. 1222, § 1, 1-1992) 
Cross reference- Solid waste, ch. 21. 
Sec. 26-4. - Entry powers of city. 
    Every person taking water from the waterworks or having connection with the sewer system shall at all reasonable times permit the superintendent of the water and sewer department or any person authorized by the city to enter his premises to examine the pipes and fixtures and the manner in which the water and sewer is used. Upon the refusal of such person to grant such privilege, the water and sewer service shall be cut off. 
(Code 1984 § 31-3) 
Sec. 26-5. - Tampering with, damaging, etc., hydrants, valves, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to carry away, obstruct, damage, or without authority, to meddle or tamper in any way with a fire hydrant, valve, meter, meter box or cover, stopcock or cover, or in any manner damage pipe, apparatus or fixtures or property of the waterworks or sewage disposal systems. When the meter or meter box shall be sealed or locked by the city, it shall be unlawful for any person to damage, destroy, tamper with or otherwise break or remove such seal or lock of the city without proper authority. 
(Code 1984 § 31-4) 
Secs. 26-6-26-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MUNICIPAL WATER SYSTEM 

Sec. 26-11. - Applications for connections or service. 
    All applications for service attachments or connections to the distributing lines or pipes of the city for the purpose of introducing water into premises shall be made by the party desiring such service. The application shall be made to the superintendent of the water and sewer department in writing and shall be filed with the clerk-treasurer. Where the premises are occupied by a lessee or renter, his application shall be accompanied by a written statement of the applicant, expressly stating that he is the responsible party who shall and will be liable for the payment of charges for such services. Where the applicant is the agent of the owner of such property, for whatever purpose, such application may be made by the agent; provided, that such application shall be accompanied by a written statement of such agent, expressly stating the name and address of the owner of such property, and that such owner is the responsible party who shall and will be liable for the payment of such charges against the property to be served. Application for water service shall be made on water blanks furnished by the superintendent of the water and sewer department and shall state fully and truly, and under oath, if required, the purpose for which the water is to be used, whereupon the superintendent of the water and sewer department shall issue the permit for such water service. 
(Code 1984 § 31-16) 
Sec. 26-12. - Authority to shut off water. 
(a)  The city reserves the right at any time without notice to shut off water in the mains for the purpose of repairs or for the violation of any of the rules of the water and sewer department. 
(b)  The city manager may direct that water service to a customer be shut off when, in the manager's opinion, continued service would directly contribute to a public health hazard existing in connection with the water or sewer service to a property. Such interruption of service may be continued until the hazardous condition is remedied. 
(c)  The city manager may direct that water service to a customer be shut off in the event of a failure to pay required utility charges or for failure to comply with sewage pretreatment requirements. Such interruption of service may be continued until the required payments, together with any penalties, are made to the city or until the pretreatment requirements have been met. 
(Code 1984 § 31-17) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to acquire, maintain, etc., water systems, NMSA 1978, §§ 3-27-1-3-27-3. 
Cross reference- Mechanical and plumbing code, § 6-26 et seq. 
Sec. 26-13. - Liability of city for service interruptions or water scarcities. 
    The city shall not be liable for damage occasioned by the unavoidable scarcity of water or the failure to furnish water occasioned by the failure of any apparatus of the city. 
(Code 1984 § 37-18) 
Sec. 26-14. - Water to be shut off during freezing weather. 
    When it is cold enough to freeze water in water pipes, water service must be shut off and the pipes emptied by consumer. 
(Code 1984 § 31-19) 
Sec. 26-15. - Stopcocks, etc., meters and meter boxes generally. 
(a)  Consumers of city water shall cause to be put in, at their own expense, a stopcock, meter and meter box. The city reserves the right to control all such meters in order that the same may be protected and served for proper operation. The street stop shall be what is known as "ground key work" with "T" handle and nut and washer bottom, and the meter box shall be of such material as shall be designated by the superintendent of the water and sewer department. It shall be the duty of the occupant of the premises or consumer of such service to keep and maintain such meter box in repair and the tops or lids thereof firmly closed and in place. 
(b)  The make and type of all meters, meter boxes and other supplies or equipment to be used, and fix the charges to the consumer therefor shall be as established by the governing body. Meters shall be located in the building or vicinity as the superintendent of the water and sewer department shall designate. 
(c)  Every service pipe must be furnished with a stop cock located inside the premises and below the frost line. Such cock shall be situated that water can be cut off and drained from the pipes. 
(d)  Water shall not be furnished to persons who do not comply with this section. 
(Code 1984 § 31-20; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 26-16. - Metering of continued flow of water. 
    No continued flow of water shall be permitted except by meters and upon payment of special rates. 
(Code 1984 § 31-21) 
Sec. 26-17. - Reading and testing meters; control of meters. 
    The billing department shall, on or before the first of each month, have water meters read and the amount shall be embraced in his monthly report for the month for which the collection is made. Should any meter fail to register properly and not show correctly the quantity of water actually used since the previous reading, in arriving at the quantity used, the right shall exist on the part of the city to average the month and charge for water on the basis of any three months within the previous year. The city reserves the right to control all such meters in order that the same may be protected and serviced for proper operation. 
(Code 1984 § 31-22; Ord. No. 1320, 4-1999) 
Sec. 26-18. - Cost of meters and fire lines. 
(a)  The following schedule of water meter purchase prices and smaller meter credit allowances are hereby established:
